This method of buying is intended to expedite the procurement of frequently needed low dollar value supplies. These blanket purchase orders will have $1,000.00 cumulative limit and no single purchase may be over $200.00. Department heads will forward a list containing the names and signatures of all personnel proposed to be authorized to sign for supplies under these agreements. Any changes to the name/signature list should be made in writing and filed with the purchasing agent. Any exceptions to this procedure will be authorized only upon receipt of an authorization signed by the county administrator or the chairperson of the finance committee or the chairperson of the board of commissioners. (b) When charging supplies, the vendor's invoice must be signed by the authorized county personnel receiving the material. Department heads will immediately forward these signed invoices to the purchasing agent. The purchasing agent must have all signed invoices in order to verify the accuracy of the vendor's monthly bills. Invoices signed by unauthorized personnel will not be paid. Sec. 2-253. - Emergency purchases. Emergency purchases may be approved by the county administrator upon the request of the appropriate department head and recommendation of the purchasing agent. The board of commissioners' finance committee will be notified as soon as practicable by the county administrator after an emergency purchase has been made. Sec. 2-254. - Receipt and inspection. The ordering agency shall ultimately be responsible for the receipt, inspection, and acceptance of the incoming supplies and equipment in compliance with the following procedure: (1) When any or all items on the purchase order have been received, inspected, and accepted, the delivery receipt shall be signed and forwarded to the purchasing agent. (2) When received items are acceptable, the receiving agency shall forward to purchasing agent a receiving report with the reason for rejection stated thereon. The purchasing agent will then arrange for the return and replacement of the defective items, or take other action as required. In the case of defective supplies, the receiving report will also be used as a rejection report. (3) When items that have already been accepted are subsequently found to be defective, the using department shall notify the purchasing agent in writing. The following information, when known, is required: a. Name of supplier. b. Purchase order number item was purchased on. c. Date defective item was received. d. Nature of defect. e. Action requested (return for credit, for replacement, etc.). (4) When items are to be received by or delivered to someone or someplace other than the suing agency, the above procedures shall be modified only to the extent that: a. Someone other than a using department employee may sign the delivery receipt, but must notify the suing agency of receipt of the order. b. Someone should satisfy themselves regarding the condition of the items, and check the items delivered against the machine copy of the purchase order. Sec. 2-255. - Payments. Most vendors offer a cash discount if their invoices are paid promptly. To take advantage of this discount policy and maintain good vendor relations, it is important that all invoices, packing slips, and receiving reports be forwarded to the purchasing agent within one working day after their receipt by the receiving department. Sec. 2-256. - Change orders. (a) Departments wishing to change or cancel an existing purchase requisition or purchase order shall issue a purchase requisition requesting such change or cancellation. The changed purchase requisition will require the same signatures as required on the original purchase requisition. Always refer to the original purchase requisition number and clearly state the action requested. (b) Upon receipt of a properly signed and processed change request purchase requisition, the purchasing agent will issue a change order to change the original purchase requisition, as required. When a change or cancellation is decided upon, the purchasing agent should be notified immediately. A few hours' notice to the purchasing agent should save the county costly restocking or cancellation charges. Sec. 2-257. - Vendor's catalog file. The purchasing agent will maintain a vendor's catalog file. Catalogs in this file will be available to all interested county employees. Sec. 2-258. - Maintenance contracts. The purchasing agent will maintain all records and information concerning county maintenance agreements. Before renewing any such agreement, the purchasing agent will check with the concerned department head and the county administrator to determine if the agreement should be renewed. Agreements found to be unnecessary or overly expensive will be terminated. Department heads will advise the purchasing agent of any change in status of items covered by maintenance agreements. A copy of the maintenance contract will be on file in the accounting office. Sec. 2-259. - Service centers. (a) An inventory of gasoline and diesel will be maintained at the prison work camp and the county landfill. When these products are issued to various departments using the driver's or operator's fuel card, they will be charged to the departments at the end of the month. (b) Tires, parts, oil and other equipment or vehicle related supplies will be charged to that vehicle or piece of equipment to determine the total cost of operation and maintenance. These costs will also be charged to the departments to which they are assigned. Sec. 2-260. - Storeroom. (a) The purchasing agent will establish and control a central storeroom for selected items such as office supplies, janitorial supplies, etc. This system will enable the purchasing agent to buy storeroom items in large quantities at a considerable cost savings as compared to buying such items as required. The storeroom method will also allow the county to standardize frequently used supplies. This includes, but is not limited to, tools, vests, gloves, office supplies, etc. (b) When a department needs any item that falls in the storeroom category, it will present a purchase requisition and present it to the purchasing agent for filling. If the requested item is not in stock, the purchasing agent will purchase it using the purchase requisition as authority to make that purchase. Requisitioned storeroom items will be charged to the appropriate department at the end of each month. Sec. 2-261. - Suggestions. Suggestions that will help reduce cost, promote efficiency, or improve supplier services are both welcome and requested. Cost reduction ideas should reduce cost without a corresponding reduction in quality of service. Secs. 2-262—2-285. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - INVESTMENT POLICY
Sec. 2-286. - Generally. It is the policy of the board of commissioners to invest public funds in accordance with state and local statutes governing the investment of public funds and meet the daily cash flow demands of the government in a manner which will provide the highest investment return with the maximum security. Sec. 2-287. - Scope. This investment policy applies to all assets of the county except as follows: (1) Any funds that are restricted from investment by law, statute, regulations or contract. (2) Investment activities by constitutional officers holding various trust and agency funds are not subject to the provisions of this policy. This does not prevent the transfer of fiduciary responsibility to the board of commissioners for investment activities. (3) Investment activity by asset managers for retirement funds and deferred compensation funds are managed under a separate agreement. (4) Paying agent funds and debt service reserve funds are managed under a separate agreement. Sec. 2-288. - Primary objectives. The primary objectives, in priority order, of the county investment program are: (1) Legality. All investments shall comply with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-83-4 and in accordance with local statutes. Investments related to bond issues which have specific investment policies contained within the bond ordinances and official statements will be adhered to and are not in conflict with the terms of this policy. (2) Safety. Investments shall be undertaken in a manner that seeks to ensure the preservation of capital in the overall portfolio. To attain this objective, diversification is required in order that potential losses on individual securities do not exceed the income generated from the remainder of the portfolio. The objective will be to mitigate credit risk and interest risk. (3) Liquidity. The investment portfolio will remain sufficiently liquid to enable the county to meet all operating requirements which might be reasonably anticipated. Investments will be managed with a "buy and hold" philosophy. (4) Yield or return on investment. The investment portfolio shall be designed with the objective of attaining a market rate of return throughout budgetary and economic cycles, taking into account the county's investment risk constraints and the cash flow characteristics of the portfolio. Sec. 2-289. - Delegation of authority. Management responsibility for the investment program is retained by the board of commissioners. The county administrator is delegated with the responsibility to establish written procedures for the operation of the investment program consistent with this investment policy. Such procedures shall include explicit delegation of authority to persons responsible for investment transactions. No person may engage in an investment transaction except as provided under the terms of this policy and the procedures established by the county administrator. The county administrator shall be responsible for all transactions undertaken and shall establish a system of internal controls to regulate the activities of subordinate officials. Sec. 2-290. - Prudence. (a) Investments shall be made with judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs, not for speculation, but for investment, considering the primary objective of safety as well as the secondary objective of obtaining market rates of return. (b) The standard of prudence to be used by investment officials shall be the "prudent person" standard and shall be applied in the context of managing an overall portfolio. Investment officers acting in accordance with written procedures and the investment policy and exercising due diligence shall be relieved of personal responsibility for an individual security's credit risk or market price changes, provided deviations from expectations are reported in a timely fashion and appropriate action is taken to control adverse developments. Sec. 2-291. - Ethics and conflicts of interest. Officers and employees involved in the investment process shall refrain from personal business activity that could conflict with proper execution of the investment program, or which could impair their ability to make impartial investment decisions. Employees and investment officials shall disclose to the county administrator any material financial interests in financial institutions that conduct business within this jurisdiction, and they shall further disclose any large personal financial/investment positions that could be related to the performance of the county's portfolio. Employees and officers shall subordinate their personal investment transactions to those of Jefferson County, particularly with regard to the time of purchases and sales. Sec. 2-292. - Investment instruments. (a) The county is empowered by O.C.G.A. § 36-83-4 to invest in the following type of securities: (1) Obligations of the State of Georgia or of any other states; (2) Obligations issued by the United States; (3) Obligations fully insured or guaranteed by the United States government or governmental agency; (4) Obligations of any corporation of the United States government; (5) Prime bankers' acceptances; (6) Georgia Fund 1, formerly known as the State of Georgia Local Government Investment Pool, and the Georgia Extended Asset Pool established by O.C.G.A. § 36-83-1 et seq.; (7) Repurchase agreements; (8) Obligations of other political subdivisions of the state; and (9) Certificates of deposit, with a pledge of collateral as provided for in O.C.G.A. §§ 45-8-12 and 50-17-59. (b) The use of derivatives as an investment instrument is prohibited. Sec. 2-293. - Collateralization. (a) Collateral securities for certificates of deposit and other investments shall be delivered to the government's depository bank for safekeeping, unless the certificate of deposit was purchased from that bank. In that event, collateral securities will be delivered to a third party bank with which the government has a fully executed and approved safekeeping agreement. (b) Securities purchased under a repurchase agreement must be delivered to the government's depository bank for safekeeping, unless the repurchase agreement is executed with that bank. In that event securities will be delivered to a third party bank as provided for in subsection (a) of this section. (c) Special requirements for repurchase agreement investments: (1) Purchased securities will be "marked to market," i.e., current market value of securities purchased must meet or exceed cost of investment plus anticipated interest earnings. (2) Margin of two percent to five percent of market value will be required in excess of cost of security plus interest. (3) Market value will be reviewed monthly during term of investment, and additional securities may have to be delivered in order to maintain margin. (4) No substitute of securities will be allowed during term of investment. This reinforces the concept that a repurchase agreement is a purchase-and-sell transaction. (5) Payment for repurchase agreement investments will be made on a "delivery versus payment" basis, i.e., funds will not be wired from the depository bank until confirmation of the securities' delivery is received from the safekeeping bank. (d) Whenever collateral securities, or securities purchased under repurchase agreements, are "book entry" type securities, e.g., U.S. Treasury bill, notes, bonds, or others, the securities shall be recorded in the name of the government by the Federal Reserve System, and appropriate confirmation shall be delivered to the government's finance department by a safekeeping bank. Sec. 2-294. - Safekeeping and custody. All investment securities which can be physically delivered shall be held in safekeeping by the government's depository bank. Securities purchased on a book entry basis shall be conducted on a "delivery versus payment" basis. This ensures that securities are deposited in the eligible financial institution prior to the release of funds. Sec. 2-295. - Competitive selection of investment instruments. (a) Competitive "bid" process shall be conducted for the investment of funds when appropriate and cost effective except those incorporated into the depository banking services agreement. If a specific maturity date is required, bids will be requested for instruments which meet the maturity requirement. If no specific maturity (within required time limitations) is required, a market trend (yield curve) analysis will be conducted to determine which maturities would be most advantageous. (b) Bids will be requested from qualified financial institutions for various options with regard to term and instrument. The government will select the bid which provides the highest effective rate of return within the maturity required and within the parameters of this policy. (c) The commissioner's office will maintain records of the bids offered, the bids accepted, and a brief explanation of the decision made regarding each investment selection. Sec. 2-296. - Authorized broker/dealers and financial institutions. (a) The commissioner's office will maintain a list of financial institutions and broker/dealers authorized to provide investment services, and from which bids may be solicited. (b) No bids will be solicited or accepted from financial institutions and broker/dealers which do not appear on the approved list. (c) In order to qualify for and remain on the approved list, these firms must provide, at least on a semi-annual basis, a consolidated report of condition. In addition, the finance department will conduct at least annually an evaluation of the firm's credit worthiness. Such evaluations may entail securing a private report from any one or more of several industry research organizations. (d) Security dealers not affiliated with banks must provide at least quarterly financial reports and be classified as reporting dealers affiliated with the New York Federal Reserve Bank, as primary dealers. Dealers covered by and subject to the regulations of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation (SIPC) insurance program are preferred. (e) Any financial institution or broker/dealer on the approved list must be registered in the state and maintain a full service office in the state. (f) Selection for and removal from the approved list shall be made by the director of finance. (g) A copy of this policy is to be provided to all qualified firms, who agree to abide by it as a condition of continuation on the approved list. Sec. 2-297. - Diversification. (a) The county will diversify use of investment instruments to avoid incurring unreasonable risks inherent in over-investing in specific instruments, individual financial institutions or maturities. (b) Diversification by instrument. MAXIMUM PERCENT OF INVESTMENT
(c) Diversification by financial institution. (1) Repurchase agreements: no more than ten percent of investment program assets with any one institution, except for overnight investment of residual concentration account balance as authorized by a master repurchase agreement incorporated into the depository banking contract. (2) Certificates of deposit (CDs): no more than 35 percent of total investment program assets of CDs with any one financial institution. (3) Bankers' acceptances: no more than ten percent of total investment program assets with any one financial institution. Sec. 2-298. - Maximum maturities. (a) Investment maturities for program assets shall be scheduled to coincide with projected cash flow needs, taking into account large or routine cash disbursements (payroll, payables, construction project payments, debt service payments) as well as considering sizeable blocks of anticipated receipts (property taxes, sales taxes, franchise fee payments). (b) Investment maturities shall be structured to comply with the following guidelines:
Sec. 2-299. - Internal controls. The county administrator shall establish a system of internal controls, which shall be documented in writing. The controls shall be designed to prevent losses of public funds arising from fraud, employee error, misrepresentation by third parties, unanticipated changes in financial markets, or imprudent actions. Sec. 2-300. - Interfund pooling authorized. The county administrator is authorized to pool cash held for operations and investments in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 36-83-6 and generally accepted accounting principles. Sec. 2-301. - Reporting. The county administrator shall submit a monthly investment report to the county commissioners that discloses all transactions made for previous quarter. The report shall also measure the investment program to predetermined performance standards. The report shall include market value information on all investments in accordance with best professional practices. An annual report on the operations of the investment program that includes 12-month comparisons of rate of return, the amounts of interest earned and the total amount available for investment shall also be prepared for review by the county commission. The Jefferson County Annual Financial Report shall include a summary of the operations of the investment program. Secs. 2-302—2-320. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - INMATE FUNDS ACCOUNTING PROCEDURE
Sec. 2-321. - Receipt and deposit of money. (a) The U.S. mail will be delivered to the designated institutional mail clerk who will open all mail. If cash, a personal check or a business check is found in the envelopes, it will be returned to the sender. If a check from a law firm, a certified check, a money order or a cashier's check is received, it will be logged in for receipt. (b) If funds come into the institution in an inmate's package, the funds will be handled the same as if they were delivered by mail. No monies will be accepted for any inmate from outside in any other fashion. (c) The dollar amount of the financial instrument will be notated on the envelope which goes to the inmate. The dollar amount of the financial instrument will be posted on the daily money order log along with the inmate's name, date of receipt, type of financial instrument and serial number or check number. (d) A copy of the daily money order log along with all checks will then be transferred to the deputy warden or his designee with an attached balancing tape. A deposit slip will be generated daily for all monies received by the deputy warden. The deposits will also include bi-weekly deposits of drink machine revenue and any checks for reimbursements of inmate store vendor (Oasis). (e) Deposits should be made at least weekly and at no time will undeposited money exceed $2,500.00. A copy of the deposit slip, the original deposit receipt and copy of the daily record of inmates' money orders will be maintained in a permanent file by the deputy warden. A copy of the deposit slips, copies the deposit receipt and a copy of the daily record of inmates' money orders will be given to the county clerk, the individual for balancing the bank account. These files will be maintained on a fiscal-year basis. Sec. 2-322. - Crediting of monies to inmate accounts. (a) The mail clerk will retain the original of the record of inmates' money orders and checks. A second copy of this log with an accompanying photocopy of the financial instruments will be given to the computer operator who will notate on the first page of the documents their initials and the time and date of receipt. (b) After the amount of each financial instrument is credited to each inmate's account, the photocopy of the check will be initialed and receipt generated reflecting the credit to the account. This receipt will then be given to the inmate. (c) After all daily posting of all deposits have occurred a summary of daily deposits will he generated and given to the deputy warden for retention in a permanent file. This file will be maintained on a fiscal year basis. (d) The store order list is turned-in by the inmate to the computer operator on Monday morning or other designated days. The store orders are to be entered into the computer (Oasis program) by the computer operator and the appropriate amounts deducted from the individuals inmate account then are downloaded to Oasis for retention. (e) A store order report will be generated. This report will be maintained by the computer operator maintained on a fiscal-year basis in a permanent file. Sec. 2-323. - Funds deducted for disciplinary reports. The deputy warden will provide the computer operator with a copy of each disciplinary report which requires a $4.00 deduction. The computer operator will deduct $4.00 from each inmate account then sign the report indicating that the deduction has been made. The disciplinary report will then be filed be a permanent file on a fiscal-year basis. A summary of these disciplinary report deductions will be printed and placed in a permanent file maintained on a fiscal-year basis by the computer operator. Sec. 2-324. - Payment of restitution. (a) When an inmate receives a disciplinary report and it is adjudicated that the inmate is to pay restitution to the institution, the warden will, upon his approval, forward the disciplinary report to the counselor. The counselor will file the original copy of the disciplinary report. The counselor will also give a copy of the disciplinary report to the computer operator, who will deduct the funds from the inmates account if the required funds are available in the account (b) If the inmate's account has insufficient funds to pay the restitution, the inmate's account will be frozen until such time as necessary funds are credited to the account by the computer operator. A copy of the receipt and the disciplinary report will be placed in a file maintained by the computer operator on a fiscal-year basis. Sec. 2-325. - Funds deducted for doctor visits. Medical staff will complete a medical deduction form when an inmate goes on sick-call or visits the doctor, dentist or other medical providers. Only one charge of $5.00 will be made per illness. The computer operator will ensure that the inmate has funds (over $10.00 after the deduction) before funds are deducted form the inmates account. If funds are available at the medical service rendered, deductions will be made as soon at the individual inmate has an adequate amount in his account. A summary of these doctor visit deductions will be printed and placed in a permanent file maintained on a fiscal-year basis by the computer operator. Sec. 2-326. - Replacement of identification card. (a) When the staff at the correctional institution determines that an inmate has lost his identification card, the staff member will notify the chief security officer who will issue the inmate a new identification (ID) card. The chief security officer then assesses the inmate a $5.00 fee for the new card. The chief security officer will complete a replacement ID card form, have the inmate sign the form, then forward the form to the warden for his approval. After being approved, the form is then forwarded to the computer operator who will deduct the funds from the inmate's account. A receipt will be generated by the computer operator and given to the inmate. A copy of the receipt and the replacement form will be placed in a file maintained by the computer operator on a fiscal-year basis. (b) In those incidents when the inmate does not have sufficient funds to pay the $5.00 charge, the ID card will be issued and the inmate's account will be assessed the $5.00 charge placing the account in a negative balance. When funds are received for the inmate, the funds will be credited to the inmates account by the computer operator. Sec. 2-327. - Funds deducted for outside purchases. (a) The computer operator will ensure that funds are available for requested purchases upon receipt of a counselor's approved inmate request to make outside purchases. If funds are not available, all forms and requests will be returned to the counselor. If funds are available, they will be deducted from the inmate's account. A notice of deduction will be generated and forwarded along with the order form and the initial inmate request form to the mail clerk for processing. The request form will be returned to the counselor for placement into the inmate's permanent file. (b) The check will be signed in accordance with this policy. The order form and the check now generated by the mail clerk will be mailed. A copy of the order form will be stapled to a copy of the check and the notice of deduction which will be transmitted to the deputy warden to be placed in a permanent file maintained on a fiscal-year basis. Sec. 2-328. - Funds deducted to transfer funds to others. (a) Upon receipt of the counselors approved request to transfer funds to others, the computer operator will ensure that funds are available for transfer. If so, appropriate funds will be deducted from the inmates account and a notice of deduction will be generated showing to whom or where funds are being sent along with the amount deducted. The request form will be signed and dated by the computer operator stating that funds were deducted from the inmates account. (b) The completed request form along with notice of deduction will be forwarded to the business manager for processing. The business manager will process the check for mailing. The check will be signed in accordance with provisions of this policy. (c) After all processing is completed, the request form and notice of deduction will be returned to the approving counselor to be placed in the inmate's permanent record file. A copy of the check, a copy of the request form and the notice of deduction will be stapled together and will be transmitted to the deputy warden to be placed in a permanent file maintained on a fiscal-year basis. Sec. 2-329. - Funds transferred to other institutions. (a) Upon receipt of orders to transfer an inmate to another institution, the computer operator will check the inmate's account to determine the balance of his account. Upon checking the inmate's account a complete financial transaction report will be generated. (b) The generated report and receipt of any balance of funds report will be forwarded to the business manager. If the inmate has a balance on his account, the business manager will process a check signed in accordance with provisions of this policy made out to the inmate for the balance of his account. (c) After the check has been processed, it, along with the transaction report, will be forwarded to the chief counselor to be placed in the inmate file being transferred to the new designated institution. A copy of the check and a copy of the transaction report will be transmitted to the deputy warden to be placed in a permanent file maintained on a fiscal-year basis. Sec. 2-330. - Funds given to inmate upon release. Upon notice from the chief counselor that an inmate is being released, paroled or discharged, the computer operator will check the inmate's account to determine if he has any funds left in his account. Upon checking the inmate's account a complete financial transaction report will be generated and forwarded to the business manager. If the inmate has any funds left in his account, the business manager will process a check signed in accordance with provisions of this policy out to the inmate being released. Once the check has been processed, the check along with his financial transaction report, will be forwarded to the chief counselor. A copy of the check and a copy of the transaction report will be transmitted to the deputy warden to be placed in a permanent file maintained on a fiscal-year basis. The inmate's account will be closed out but will not be deleted from the computer files. Sec. 2-331. - Processing of checks. All checks will require two individuals to sign each check. These individuals will be preauthorized, in writing by the warden to sign these checks. Authorized signature cards will be on file at the bank. These signature cards will be updated as the staff changes dictate. Sec. 2-332. - Generating scheduled activity reports. On the last day of each month the computer operator will generate an inmate account balance report then place the report in a permanent file maintained on a fiscal-year basis in the computer operator's office. Secs. 2-333—2-350. - Reserved. DIVISION 6. - FINANCIAL POLICY Subdivision 1. - In General
Sec. 2-351. - Purpose. To ensure the effective and economical use of public resources by promoting sound financial management practices. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-352. - Policy. (a) The board of commissioners (the board) and staff of Jefferson County (the County) recognize the desirability of stated financial policies to assist in meeting the county government's basic objectives: (1) The policies will assist the county in the objective of being publicly accountable and assist users of the financial statement to assess that accountability. (2) The policies will assist in meeting and evaluating the operating results of county government. (3) The policies will assist in determining the level of services that can be provided, the cost of services, and the county's ability to provide those services. (b) The county recognizes that the process of developing policies and supporting procedures to implement the policies is a dynamic process that must be continually reviewed. Accordingly, the county expects these policies to become a significant part of its system of internal control and provide the following benefits: (1) Reduce misunderstanding, duplication of effort, errors and inefficiency. (2) Provide a comprehensive, consistent methodology for similar transactions. (3) Insure the use of proper, accurate, and timely financial information. (4) Provide training to new or inexperienced employees to insure uniform, consistent application of policies. (5) Provide a basic framework for a system of internal control. (6) Provide a fixed point of reference for those who wish to evaluate the county's operations and financial reporting. (7) Reduce or eliminate informal policies now in existence. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Secs. 2-353—2-370. - Reserved. Subdivision 2. - Accounting and Financial Reporting
Sec. 2-371. - Purpose. The County is committed to preparing financial reports which are in accordance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), standards set by the Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB), and laws of the State of Georgia. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-372. - Policy. (a) The county shall produce interim reports as needed to ensure budgetary control of operations and capital programs. (b) The county's accounting and financial reporting systems will be maintained in conformance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and standards of the Government Accounting Standards Board (GASB). (c) An annual audit will be performed by an independent public accounting firm with the subsequent issue of an annual financial report, including an audit opinion. (d) All funds of the county, as well as all component units, will be subject to a full scope audit. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Secs. 2-373—2-390. - Reserved. Subdivision 3. - Revenue
Sec. 2-391. - Purpose. The county shall attempt to maintain a diversified and stable revenue system to shelter it from short-run fluctuations in any single revenue source. The revenue mix shall combine elastic and inelastic revenue sources to minimize the effect of an economic downturn. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-392. - Policy. (a) The county will estimate its annual revenues by an objective analytical and conservative process utilizing trend, judgmental, and statistical analysis as appropriate. (b) Each existing and potential revenue source will be re-examined annually. (c) The county will aggressively seek public and private grants, contracts, and other outside sources of funding projects when appropriate. (d) The county shall follow an aggressive policy of collecting revenues. (e) User fees will be adjusted annually to recover the full cost of services provided, except when the county commission determines that a subsidy from the general fund is in the public interest. (f) One-time revenues will be used for one-time expenditures only. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Secs. 2-393—2-410. - Reserved. Subdivision 4. - Reserves/Governmental Funds
Sec. 2-411. - Purpose. The accumulation of reserves protects the county from uncontrollable increases in expenditures, extraordinary losses, unforeseen reductions in revenues, or a combination of these items. It also allows for prudent replacement and financing of capital construction and replacement projects. With the implementation of GASB Statement No. 54, Fund Balance Reporting and Governmental Fund Type Definitions, the overall definitions and classifications of governmental fund balances have changed. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-412. - Policy. Fund equity in the governmental fund financial statements is classified as fund balance. Generally, fund balance represents the difference between current assets and current liabilities. In the fund financial statements, governmental funds report fund balance classifications that comprise a hierarchy based primarily on the extent to which the county is bound to honor constraints on the specific purposes for which amounts in those funds can be spent. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-413. - Classifications. (a) Nonspendable — (Inherently nonspendable). Fund balances are reported as nonspendable when amounts cannot be spent because they are either (a) not in spendable form (such as inventory or prepaids) or (b) legally or contractually required to be maintained intact (such as the principal of an endowment fund). (b) Restricted — (Externally enforceable limitations on use). Fund balances are reported as restricted when there are limitations imposed on their use either through the enabling legislation adopted by the county or through external restrictions imposed by creditors, grantors, contributors, or laws or regulations of other governments or imposed by law through state statute. (c) Committed — (Self-imposed limitations set in place prior to the end of the period). Fund balances are reported as committed when they can be used only for specific purposes pursuant to constraints imposed by formal action of the board through the adoption of a formal policy. Only the Board may modify or rescind the commitment. (d) Assigned — (Limitation resulting from intended use). Fund balances are reported as assigned when amounts are constrained by the board's intent to be used for specific purposes, but are neither restricted nor committed. Authorization to assign fund balance remains with the board. (e) Unassigned — (Residual net resources). Fund balances are reported as unassigned when the balance does not meet any of the above criterion. The county reports positive unassigned fund balance in the general fund only. Negative unassigned fund balances may be reported in all governmental funds. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-414. - Flow assumptions. When both restricted and unrestricted amounts of fund balance are available for use for expenditures incurred, the county shall use restricted amounts first and then unrestricted amounts as they are needed. For unrestricted amounts of fund balance, the county shall use fund balance in the following order: • Committed • Assigned • Unassigned (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-415. - Minimum fund balance. The county will make every feasible effort to maintain a general fund unassigned fund balance of not less than 25 percent of the annual operating budget. This minimum fund balance, which may only be used as required by authority of the board, is to provide for operating contingencies in either revenues or expenditures, and to provide adequate funds to operate without short-term borrowing. In the event the unassigned fund balance falls below the minimum amount, the county administrator will present a plan to the board as part of the subsequent fiscal year's annual budget to replenish the fund balance to the established minimum level in a reasonable time frame, generally one to three years. Budget surpluses will first be used towards replenishment, followed by the use of non-recurring revenues. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-416. - Contingency. A contingency amount shall be appropriated annually as part of the budget within the general fund, and other funds as deemed necessary, and shall be used for paying unexpected or unanticipated expenditures of an operational nature during the fiscal year. Within the general fund, this amount should approximate one to two percent of the general fund budget. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Secs. 2-417—2-430. - Reserved. Subdivision 5. - Budget Preparation
Sec. 2-431. - Purpose. The budget serves as an important management tool providing information essential to improving the efficiency of program operations and as an accountability document providing information that citizens can use in assessing county activities and operations. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-432. - Responsibility. The county administrator prepares the budget and is responsible for coordinating the work of his or her staff as well as the budget activities of the department managers. (1) By March 1, the county administrator shall prepare a budget calendar and distribute budget preparation information to all departments. Included shall be actual or estimated budget information for the current and prior years. Guidelines showing the limits with which the budget requests should be prepared shall be included. (2) The county administrator shall be responsible for seeing that the calendar is met at each stage of approval. He or she may adjust the calendar as necessary to the extent it does not violate statutory requirements. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-433. - Policy. (a) The fiscal year for the county shall begin July 1 and end June 30 of each year. (b) The operating budgets originally adopted may be amended throughout the year by the board subject to provisions of Georgia state law and as herein contained. (c) The county shall finance current expenditures with current revenues. (d) All revenues which are reasonably expected to be unexpended and unencumbered at the end of the fiscal year shall be anticipated as "fund balance" in the budget of the following year. (e) The budget shall provide for adequate maintenance of capital equipment and facilities and for its orderly replacement. (f) All funds except trust and agency funds and the sheriffs federal and state condemnation funds are subject to the annual budget process (g) The budget must be balanced for all budgeted funds. Total anticipated revenues must equal total estimated expenditures for the general, special revenue, and capital project funds. (h) All budgets shall be adopted on a basis of accounting consistent with generally accepted accounting principles. Revenues are budgeted when they become measurable and available. Expenditures are charged against the budget when they become measurable, a liability has been incurred, and the liability shall be liquidated with current resources. (i) The budget shall be adopted at the legal level of budgetary control which is the fund/department level. Expenditures may not exceed the total for any department within a fund without the approval of the board. (j) The county shall include a line item in the general fund for unforeseen, emergency operating expenditures. The amount of this contingency is detailed in the fund reserve policies. (k) The county shall maintain a budgetary control system to ensure adherence to the budget and will have available timely monthly financial reports comparing actual revenues, expenditures, and encumbrances with budgeted amounts. (l) The budget shall reflect both fixed and variable costs whenever practical. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-434. - Budget amendments. (a) Transfers within departments may be authorized by the county administrator. (b) Transfers between departments or funds shall be by authority of the board. (c) Increase or decrease in the total fund appropriation shall be by authority of the board. (d) Increase or decrease in salary appropriation within any department shall be determined through the annual budget process. (e) Appropriation of fund balances shall be by authority of the board. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-435. - Budget increases. Funds must limit expenditures to current year revenues except in the following instances: (1) Prior year encumbrances. Prior year open purchase orders act as a reserve against fund balance and will reduce fund balance when paid. (2) Unanticipated revenue. Unanticipated revenue shall first be committed to satisfy revenue reserve requirements and then may be appropriated for current year nonrecurring expenditures. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-436. - Budget decreases. Where economic conditions dictate, budgets may be decreased to levels below adopted appropriations. The county administrator shall notify departments of the anticipated level of reductions detailing the order of preference in reductions. Amounts decreased from specific line items in each fund shall be entered as a line item entitled "frozen appropriations". This does not automatically decrease appropriations, but prevents expenditures until such time as budget amounts are available for appropriation. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-437. - Lapsing of appropriations. Unexpended appropriations at the end of the fiscal year shall lapse into the fund balance. Those amounts cannot be spent unless re-appropriated in the succeeding fiscal year with certain exceptions: (1) Capital projects, excluding equipment. Appropriations for capital projects do not automatically lapse at the end of the fiscal year. However, carryover must be budgeted by the department for the following fiscal year and re-appropriated by the board. (2) Grant funds. Appropriations funded by state or federal grants lapse only at the expiration of a grant or completion of the project. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Secs. 2-438—2-450. - Reserved. Subdivision 6. - Debt Administration
Sec. 2-451. - Purpose. The county shall seek to maintain and, if possible, improve its current municipal bond rating so that borrowing costs are minimized and access to credit preserved. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-452. - Policy. (a) The county shall develop adequate reserves to avoid the necessity of short-term borrowing to finance operating needs. In the interim, financing in anticipation of a definite fixed source of revenue, such as tax anticipation notes, is acceptable. (b) The issuance of long-term debt shall be limited to capital improvements or projects which cannot be financed from current revenues or resources. (c) Every effort shall be made to limit the long-term debt maturity schedule to no longer than the estimated useful life of the capital projects or improvements to be financed. (d) When the county utilizes either long-term or short-term debt it shall insure that the debt is financed soundly by: (1) Conservatively projecting the revenue sources which will repay the debt. (2) Financing the improvement over a period not greater than the useful life of the improvement for long-term debt, or December 31 of the calendar year for short-term debt. (3) Determining that the cost benefit of the improvement, including interest and any other costs, is positive. (e) The county shall limit the total of its general obligation long-term borrowing to ten percent of its net assessed property value. Short-term borrowing shall be limited to 75 percent of the source of revenue expected to repay the loan. (f) Capital leases may be used to finance equipment purchases when the total cost of the equipment purchases exceed three percent of the budget for the fund in which they originate. (g) The county shall maintain a debt service fund which is equivalent to the amount of general obligation debt maturing in the subsequent year. (h) Whenever possible the county will finance capital projects by using self-supporting revenue bonds since revenue bonds assure the greatest degree of equity because those who benefit from a project and those who pay for a project are most closely matched. (i) General obligation debt shall not be used for enterprise activities. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-453. - Debt planning policies. When the county is considering a possible bond issue, the county administrator shall develop information and present its findings to the board concerning the following categories: (1) Debt analysis. a. Debt capacity analysis. b. Purposes for which debt is issued. c. Debt structure. d. Debt burden and magnitude indicators and ratios as compared to other like communities. e. Debt history and trends. f. Adequacy of debt and capital planning. g. Obsolescence of capital plan. (2) Financial analysis. a. Stability, diversity, and growth rate of tax sources. b. Trends in assessed valuation and collections. c. Current budget trends. d. Appraisal of past revenue and expenditure estimates. e. Evidences of financial planning. f. History and long-term trends of revenues and expenditures. g. Adherence to Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). h. Audit results. i. Liquidity of portfolio and other current assets. j. Fund balance status and trends. k. Financial monitoring systems and capabilities. (3) Governmental and administrative analysis. a. Government organization structure. b. Location of financial responsibilities and degree of control. c. Adequacy of basic service provision. d. Intergovernmental cooperation/conflict and extent of duplication. e. Overall county planning efforts. (4) Economic analysis. a. Geographic and location advantages. b. Population and demographic characteristics. c. Wealth indicators. d. Housing characteristics. e. Level of new construction. f. Types of employment, industry and occupation. g. Evidences of industrial or other decline. h. Trend of the economy. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-454. - Communication and disclosure. (a) The county will maintain good communications with bond rating agencies to inform them about the county's financial condition. The county shall follow a policy of full disclosure. Significant financial reports affecting or commenting on the county will be forwarded to the rating agencies. (b) The county will continue to improve communications with other jurisdictions with which a common property tax base is shared concerning collective plans for future debt issues. Reciprocally shared information on debt plans including amounts, purposes, timing, and types of debt would aid each jurisdiction in its debt planning decisions. (Policy of 4-16-2014) Sec. 2-455. - Refunding bonds. (a) The county should evaluate the following when considering a refunding candidate: (1) Issuance costs that will be incurred. (2) The interest rate at which the refunding bonds can be issued. (3) The maturity date of the refunded bonds. (4) The call date of the refunded bonds. (5) The call premium on the refunded bonds. (6) The structure and yield of the refunding escrow. (7) Any transferred proceeds penalty. (b) Financial and policy objectives. The county may undertake a refunding to achieve debt service savings, eliminate restrictive bond/legal covenants, or restructure the stream of debt service payments. (c) Financial savings/results. (1) The refunding should achieve a minimum net present value savings (savings net of all issuance costs and any cash contribution that may be required) of no less than three percent to five percent or $1,000,000.00. This test can be applied to the entire issue or on a maturity-by-maturity basis. (2) Federal law permits an issuer to conduct one advance refunding over the life of a bond issue. As such, a higher savings threshold may be required when evaluating an advance refunding candidate. (3) In certain circumstances, lower savings thresholds may be justified. Such instances include when a refunding is being conducted primarily for policy reasons, interest rates are at historically low levels, or the time remaining to maturity is limited making future opportunities to achieve greater savings not likely. (d) Bond structure. When bonds are issued, the county should anticipate the potential for refundings in the future. Careful attention should be paid to the bond structure to address features that may affect flexibility in the future. (Policy of 4-16-2014)

div.head: Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Georgia Alcoholic Beverage Code, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.; regulation of alcoholic beverages generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-1 et seq.; authority of local authorities to license and regulate alcoholic beverage sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2; local regulation of sales on Sundays, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; prohibited acts on licensed premises, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-40 et seq.; malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-1 et seq.; wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-1 et seq.; local licensing requirements for sale of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; requirements for sale of wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Alcohol means ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, from whatever source or by whatever process produced. Alcoholic beverage means and includes all alcohol, distilled spirits, beer, malt beverage, wine or fortified wine. Beer means malt beverage, as that term is defined in this section. Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than 14 percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer and strong beer. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel or other original consumer container. Retailer or retail dealer means, except as to distilled spirits, any person who sells alcoholic beverages, either in unbroken packages or for consumption on the premises, at retail only to consumers and not for resale. With respect to distilled spirits, the term means any person who sells distilled spirits in unbroken packages at retail only to consumers and not for resale. Wholesaler or wholesale dealer means any person who sells alcoholic beverages to other wholesale dealers, to retail dealers, or to retail consumption dealers. Wine means any alcoholic beverage containing not more than 21 percent alcohol by volume made from fruits, berries or grapes either by natural fermentation or by natural fermentation with brandy added. The term "wine" includes, but is not limited to, all sparkling wines and champagnes or combinations of such beverages, vermouths, special natural wines, rectified wines and like products. The term "wine" does not include cooking wine mixed with salt or other ingredients so as to render it unfit for human consumption as a beverage. A liquid shall first be deemed to be a wine at that point in the manufacturing process when it conforms to the definition of wine contained in this section. (Code 1996, § 6-26) State Law reference— Similar definitions, O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. Sec. 4-2. - Waiver of provisions. All notices and other procedural rights and provisions provided for in this chapter may be waived, and shall be deemed to have been waived unless timely objection has been made thereto. No defect in any notice, statement of grounds, or of the proper mailing or service thereof shall be valid unless written objection pointing out the grounds thereof are filed with the office of the board of commissioners at least two days prior to any scheduled hearing or action thereon. (Code 1996, § 6-52; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 25) Secs. 4-3—4-22. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MALT BEVERAGES AND WINE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 4-23—4-47. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSES
Sec. 4-48. - Sales license required. No beer or wine shall be sold in the unincorporated area of the county except at an established place of business which has been issued a license as provided in this division. (Code 1996, § 6-27(a); Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 1) State Law reference— Local license requirements for malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq.; county license for dealing in malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-41; local license requirements for wine, O.C.G.A. § 3-6-40. Sec. 4-49. - Qualifications for licensure. A license shall be granted only to a natural person who is an owner, officer or manager of the proposed business, for the one establishment at the address stated in the license. No license shall be granted to any person who is not at least 21 years of age, of good moral character, financially responsible, who meets all requirements of state and federal laws and regulations governing the sale of such beverages, and who has submitted a proper application and complied with all provisions of this article. (Code 1996, § 6-27(b); Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 1) State Law reference— Discretion and due process as to granting or suspension of permits by local governing authorities, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. Sec. 4-50. - Classes; license fees. (a) Class A license—Consumption on and off premises. Class A licenses shall authorize the retail sale of beer and of wine for consumption both on and off the premises. Class A licenses shall be issued only for restaurants and clubs. As used in this section, the term "restaurant" shall mean a business which serves hot food prepared on the premises, and the term "club" shall mean a bona fide membership club having definitely established membership requirements and admission procedures. Such restaurants and clubs shall have a seating capacity of at least 20 people. The annual fee for such license shall be as established by the board of commissioners from time to time for a class A wine license and as established by the board of commissioners from time to time for a class A beer license. (b) Class B license—Off premises consumption only. Class B licenses shall authorize the retail sale of beer and of wine only in the unbroken package for takeout and consumption off the premises. The annual fee for such licenses shall be as established by the board of commissioners from time to time for a class B wine license and as established by the board of commissioners from time to time for a class B beer license. (c) Wholesale license. A fee as established by the board of commissioners from time to time per year shall be charged to wholesale beer and wine dealers operating in the county. (Code 1996, §§ 6-29, 6-30; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 3; Ord. of 8-11-1981) State Law reference— Limitation on wholesale dealer license fees by county other than that in which business is located, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-43. Sec. 4-51. - Separate license required for each establishment. A separate license under this article shall be required for each separate establishment regardless of ownership. (Code 1996, § 6-31; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 3(c)) Sec. 4-52. - License applications; advertisements; fee. All applications for licenses under this article shall be made in writing on forms to be furnished by the board of commissioners. The application shall disclose that the applicant has furnished the county sheriff's department with the fingerprints of the applicant as required by state law. Each such application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee as established by the board of commissioners from time to time in the form of a certified check, cashier's check or money order. Upon receipt thereof in proper form, the board of commissioners shall cause a notice of the application to be published once a week for three weeks in the newspaper in which sheriff's advertisements for the county are published. (Code 1996, § 6-32; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 4) Sec. 4-53. - Contents of license application. All applications for licenses under this article shall be verified by the applicant, and shall disclose, in addition to such other information as may be required, the following: (1) The name, residence, location and mailing address of the applicant. (2) Whether the license is for a business which is an individual proprietorship, partnership, corporation or trade name. If a corporation, the application shall include the names and addresses of all shareholders, directors, officers and real parties in interest. If a partnership, the application shall state the names and addresses of all partners therein. If a trade name or individual, the application shall also state the names and addresses of all owners or parties having an interest therein. In any event, the application shall state the names of all persons, firms or corporations holding any security or other interest in the business or any part thereof. (3) The location at which the establishment is to be conducted, and a description of the building in which the business is to be conducted, indicating the size and type of construction. (4) Whether the applicant or any partner, shareholder, director, officer, owner or real party in interest in the business has been convicted during the last ten years of any crime (other than minor traffic offenses) in any state, county, municipal or federal court, and the particulars of the conviction. (5) The prior addresses of the applicant for the past ten years. (6) Names and addresses of three persons who have known the applicant for the past five years. (7) Whether the applicant or any shareholder, officer, director or other person connected therewith holds or has held any beer, wine or liquor license in the state at any time prior to the application, and the particulars thereof. (8) The name and address of the person who will manage the establishment or be responsible for its operation. (9) Such other information as the board of commissioners or the sheriff of the county may require, either initially, at any time during consideration of the application, or at any time thereafter. (10) The application shall affirmatively state that the granting of the license will create no violation of section 4-61. (Code 1996, § 6-33; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 5) Sec. 4-54. - Notice to sheriff; filing of recommendation. The board of commissioners shall furnish a copy of each application for a license under this article to the sheriff, who shall file his recommendation with the board within 15 days thereafter. (Code 1996, § 6-34; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 6) Sec. 4-55. - Objections to issuance of license. Any citizen or person residing or doing business in the county may file objections in writing to any application for license under this article. Such objections shall be filed not later than three days after publication of the last advertisement required under this division. Such objections shall state the name and address of the objector, the interest of the objector and how objector would be affected by grant of the license, the distance in miles from the objector's residence or place of business to the establishment of the proposed license, the nature of the objection and the grounds thereof, and, when the objection is filed on behalf of a group of persons, the name and address of a representative of the group authorized to receive notices relating to the application and all hearings thereon. It shall not be a valid objection to the issuance of a license that the objector is opposed generally to the sale of alcoholic or malt beverages. (Code 1996, § 6-35; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 7) Sec. 4-56. - Notice to applicant of objections filed; notice of hearing. A copy of all objections filed as provided in this division shall be mailed to the applicant at the address stated in the application by certified mail, return receipt requested. Both the objectors and the applicant shall be given notice of the time and place of a hearing on the application by certified mail, return receipt requested, deposited in the U.S. mail at least five days prior to the hearing. (Code 1996, § 6-36; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 8) Sec. 4-57. - Uncontested applications. If the license application under this article is in proper form and no valid objections have been filed thereto, if the sheriff has not recommended against grant of the license, and if no valid reason appears why the license should not be granted, the license may be issued, without hearing, upon receipt of the applicable fee therefor in the form of a certified check, cashier's check or money order. (Code 1996, § 6-37; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 9) Sec. 4-58. - Contested or denied applications; hearings. No license under this article shall be denied except after opportunity for a hearing has been given as provided in this article. If valid objections have been filed to the application, or if the sheriff has recommended against the application, or if the board of commissioners has reason to believe that grounds may exist for denying the license, the board chairperson shall schedule the matter for hearing before the board of commissioners and give notice of the time and place of the hearing as provided in this division. (Code 1996, § 6-38; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 10) Sec. 4-59. - Hearing procedure. At the hearing before the board of commissioners or a majority of the board, the strict rules of evidence and procedure prevailing in courts of law shall not apply. The county attorney is designated as hearing officer to conduct the hearing. No objections filed by any person shall be considered unless such person or a representative is present at the hearing and presents evidence in support thereof. If the applicant fails to appear at any hearing on the application, the application shall be denied forthwith without hearing, and if the applicant fails to furnish any information or to produce any records reasonably required by county authorities, the application may be denied without consideration of the merits thereof. Except when prevented by providential cause or due to the fault of the applicant, all applications shall be finally determined within 90 days of the filing thereof. (Code 1996, § 6-39; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 11) Sec. 4-60. - Standards for consideration. In considering applications for licenses under this article, the board of commissioners shall be guided by the following: (1) The moral character, reputation and prior record of the applicant and of any shareholder, director, officer, agent or employee or any person having any interest in the proposed establishment. (2) The credit standing of the applicant and his reputation for payment of bills, debts and obligations. (3) Whether the location of the proposed establishment would present a hazard to pedestrian or vehicular traffic. (4) The number of existing licenses within the immediate vicinity of the location of the proposed establishment. (5) The character of the community or neighborhood in which the establishment is to be located—whether residential, commercial or industrial. (6) Any valid objections made in writing by any person as provided in this division. (7) Whether the applicant has furnished false information in connection with the application. (8) Whether the proposed establishment has complied with all other state, federal and local laws or regulations, including but not limited to, those promulgated by the state and local boards of health, and the state fire marshal. (9) The number of such establishments or licenses already owned or held by the applicant or any other person connected therewith. (10) If the applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell beer and wine, whether or not he has violated any law, regulation or ordinance relating to such business. (11) If applicant is a previous holder of a license to sell beer or wine, the manner in which he conducted the business thereunder as to the necessity for unusual police observation and inspection in order to prevent the violation of any law, regulation or ordinance relating to the business. (12) Whether the applicant or anyone connected therewith has previously had a beer or wine license suspended or revoked. (Code 1996, § 6-41; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 13) Sec. 4-61. - Proximity to schools, churches, or playgrounds. (a) No license shall be issued under this article when the place of business of the licensee is located within 200 yards of any church, school, park or playground. As used in this section, the term "park or playground" shall include or refer to parks or playgrounds owned or operated by the county or any municipality therein. (b) All distances set forth in this section shall be measured by way of the nearest traveled road, street or highway. Measurement shall be from the property line of school, church, park or playground to the entrance of the building or proposed building where such beverages are proposed to be sold. (Code 1996, § 6-40; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 12) State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Sec. 4-62. - Timely commencement of business. All licensees under this article must, within 90 days after the approval of the license, open for business the establishment referred to in the application and license and begin the sale of the products authorized by the license. Failure to open the establishment and begin the sale as referred to above within the 90-day period shall serve as automatic forfeiture and cancellation of the unused license and no refund of license fee shall be made to the license holder. Extensions of time under this section may be granted by the board of commissioners. (Code 1996, § 6-47; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 20) Sec. 4-63. - Ceasing operation of business; forfeiture of license. Any holder of a license under this article who shall begin the operation of the business and sale of the products as authorized in any license, but who shall for a period of 90 consecutive days thereafter cease to operate the business and sale of the products authorized in the license, shall automatically forfeit his license. (Code 1996, § 6-48; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 21) Sec. 4-64. - Display of license. The county license issued under this article shall at all times be kept plainly exposed to view at the place of business of the licensee. (Code 1996, § 6-49; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 22) State Law reference— Display of state license required, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-3. Sec. 4-65. - Duration of license. All licenses under this article shall be issued for a period of one year, effective from January 1 through December 31 of each year. (Code 1996, § 6-28; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 2) Sec. 4-66. - License transfers. No license granted under this article shall be transferred. (Code 1996, § 6-42; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 14) Sec. 4-67. - Renewal. Licenses are granted for one year at a time, and no person acquires any property interest or expectancy of continuation by reason of the grant of any license hereunder. All applications for renewal of an existing license must provide proof to the commissioners upon renewal of an existing license that the applicant has complied with the Georgia Department of Revenue regulations and has a license from the State of Georgia Department of Revenue to sell beer and wine for the previous license period. Failure to provide proof that the applicant complied with state law during the previous license period will automatically deny the applicant the right to have his or her beer and wine license renewed in his or her name or any other person's name at the location of the establishment. All applications for renewal of an existing license shall be filed in writing between November 1 and December 1 of each year and shall furnish such information as the commissioners may require and shall be accompanied by the license fee [as] set forth in section 4-50 hereof. The renewal license shall be granted unless the commission has reason to believe that good cause exists for denying the renewal, in which event the applicant shall be given notice in writing setting forth the grounds upon which the license renewal may be denied. Such notice shall be mailed to the applicant by certified mail at least five days prior to the hearing to be held thereon, and shall give notice of the time and place of the hearing. In all other respects, the same procedures and requirements shall govern the granting or denial of the renewal license as set forth in sections 4-58, 4-59, and 4-60 [of this article]. (Code 1996, § 6-43; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 15; Ord. of 9-13-2011, § 15) Sec. 4-68. - Inspection of establishments. All establishments operating under a license granted under this article shall be subject to inspection by the sheriff and other state and county authorities at any time without prior notice, warrant or authority. (Code 1996, § 6-45; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 17) Sec. 4-69. - Immediate suspension authorized. If visible evidence is discovered that there is taking place in the establishment any type of gambling, prostitution, narcotics or anything offensive to the general public, the license under this article will be suspended immediately and will be subject to revocation as set forth in this article. (Code 1996, § 6-53; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 29) Sec. 4-70. - Revocation of license. (a) Any license granted under this article may be revoked, after notice and opportunity for hearing, for: (1) Conviction of a violation of any law or regulation of any state or the federal government (other than minor traffic and other minor offenses having no relationship to the applicant's fitness to sell beer or wine). (2) Violation of any provision of this article or of any other state or county regulations. (3) Furnishing false information in connection with any license application or renewal application. (b) The applicant shall be given notice in writing, stating the grounds for such revocation, and the time and place of the hearing thereon. Such notice shall be mailed to the licensee by certified mail, return receipt requested, at least five days prior to the hearing or shall be served in person on the licensee at least three days prior to the hearing. In all other respects, the same administrative procedures and provisions set forth in this division shall govern such revocation proceedings. (Code 1996, § 6-46; Ord. of 5-15-1981(12), § 18) Secs. 4-71—4-98. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - SINGLE DAY SPECIAL EVENT PERMITS
Sec. 4-99. - State permit required. Persons or organizations desiring to sell, provide, or allow alcoholic beverages at a special event within the unincorporated areas of the county shall apply to the state department of revenue for a temporary special event permit authorizing the organization to sell, distribute, or allow beer and wine for consumption only on the premises for a period not to exceed one day, which cannot include any Sunday of the year or Christmas Day, and subject to the rules and regulations of the state department of revenue. Sec. 4-100. - County permit. Upon proof of issuance of the state permit, the organization may apply to the county for a single-day special event permit. If the provisions of this division are met, the permit shall be issued at no charge, subject to the following: (1) The event must comply with the times and days allowed for selling alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises. (2) No more than six permits for a maximum of one day at a time shall be issued to an applicant in any one calendar year. (3) The special event must receive approval from the county sheriff's office on crowd control, parking and security measures. (4) The location at which the event is to take place must be approved in writing by the owner of the property. Sec. 4-101. - Revocation. The temporary permit may be immediately revoked if it is determined by law enforcement that underage persons are being provided alcohol or if there is a disturbance of the peace or any other danger to the health, safety or welfare of the public. Sec. 4-102. - Indemnification of county required. As a condition of the issuance of a temporary special event permit, the permittee shall indemnify and hold the county harmless from any claims, demands or causes of action which may arise from activities associated with the special event. Sec. 4-103. - Eating establishment rules not applicable. The requirements of an eating establishment, number of seats, and percentage of sales shall not apply to a temporary special event permit. Secs. 4-104—4-134. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - OPERATIONS
Sec. 4-135. - Copy of article to be kept on premises; employees to receive instruction. It shall be the duty of the management of the premises licensed under this article to maintain a copy of this article on the premises and to instruct each employee on the terms of this article. (Code 1996, § 6-50; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 23) Sec. 4-136. - Hours and days of sale. (a) Licensees under this article shall not engage in the sale of beer or wine between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. (b) No beer or wine shall be sold, bartered or given away: (1) On Sunday; (2) To any person who is obviously already under the influence thereof, or of any drugs; (3) To any minor; (4) To any person who is mentally incompetent; (5) On the day of any state, national or county election, including any primary or runoff election, during the hours the polls are open; (6) On Thanksgiving Day and Christmas Day. (Code 1996, § 6-44; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 16) State Law reference— Sale of alcoholic beverages on Sundays, election days, and Christmas Day generally, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20; local regulation of Sunday sales, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-7; sale of alcoholic beverage to intoxicated person, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-22; furnishing to, possession of, or purchase of alcoholic beverages by persons under 21 years of age, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23. Sec. 4-137. - Building requirements. No beer or wine shall be sold under any license granted pursuant to this article in any temporary structure, in any dilapidated structure or in any building or other structure which is not safe for human habitation. (Code 1996, § 6-51; Ord. of 5-15-1981(1), § 24)

div.head: Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Licensing and registration of animals by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-3; livestock running at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; disposal of diseased, disabled, or dead animals, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq.; dogs generally, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-1; dangerous dog control, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; vicious dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-40 et seq.; animal protection, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; cruelty to dogs; authorized killing of dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-5; rabies control, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority, inflicts a severe injury on a human being on public or private property or aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of humans without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potential dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. A dog that inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out the law enforcement officer's official duties shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article. A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this article if the injury inflicted by the dog was sustained by a person who, at the time, was committing a willful trespass or other tort or was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog or had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused or assaulted the dog, or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. Dog control officer means an individual selected by a local government pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 4-8-22 to aid in the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Local government means any county or municipality of this state. Owner means any natural person or any local entity, including but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm or trust, owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within this county. Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that without provocation bites a human being on public or private property.
