(b) Used nondisposable instruments shall be kept in a separate puncture-resistant container until brush-scrubbed in hot water and soap, and then sterilized by autoclaving. (c) The following procedures should be followed during the sterilization process: (1) Prior to being placed in the autoclave all equipment shall be bagged, dated and sealed. (2) Each autoclave bag may hold no more than one liner and shader tube with needle and bar inserted into tube. (3) To protect needle tips from damage, an appropriate sterile protective covering shall be placed on the needle tip. (4) Instruments shall remain in the autoclave 55 minutes from a cold start. (5) If the process begins with a hot start then instruments should be processed for 35 minutes. (6) To achieve proper sterilization, temperature must reach 273 degrees Fahrenheit and 15-30 psi. (7) Spore indicators shall be used with each load to ensure spore eradication. Sec. 18-29. - Tattoo preparation. (a) Before placing the tattoo design on the client's skin, the artist shall treat the skin area with an antibacterial solution. (b) If an acetate stencil is used by a tattoo artist for transferring the design to the skin, it shall be thoroughly cleaned and rinsed in a germicidal solution for at least 20 minutes and then dried with sterile gauze or dried in the air on a sanitized surface after each use. (c) If a paper-stencil is used by a tattoo artist for transferring the design to the skin, it shall be single-use disposable. (d) If the design is drawn directly onto the skin, it shall be applied with a single-use article only. Sec. 18-30. - After tattoo application. (a) The completed tattoo shall be washed with a single-use towel saturated with an antibacterial solution. (b) After the area has dried, a thick layer of antibacterial ointment from a collapsible or plastic tube shall be applied. (c) A bandage shall then be applied to the tattoo using a sealed Telfa (non-sticking) pad. (d) The client should then be given written instructions on caring for the tattoo during the healing process. Sec. 18-31. - Disinfection of workplace. Each tattoo studio must be kept clean and sanitary. The owner must develop and implement a cleaning schedule that includes appropriate methods of decontamination and tasks or procedures to be performed. This written schedule must be based on the location within the studio, the type of surfaces to be cleaned, type of possible contamination present, the tasks or procedures to be performed, and their location within the studio. The following procedures shall be adhered to: (1) Clean and sanitize all equipment and work surfaces with an appropriate disinfectant after completion of tattoo procedures and at the end of work shift when surfaces have become contaminated since the last cleaning. (2) Remove and replace protective coverings such as plastic wrap and aluminum foil after each tattoo procedure. (3) Inspect and decontaminate, on a regular basis, reusable receptacles such as bins, pails, and cans that have a likelihood for becoming contaminated. When contamination is visible, clean and decontaminate receptacles immediately or as soon as feasible. Sec. 18-32. - Disposal of waste. (a) Needles, razors, or other sharp instruments used during tattoo procedures, shall be placed in puncture resistant, closed containers immediately after use. (b) Needles shall not be purposely bent or broken, or otherwise manipulated by hand. (c) Containers of sharp waste shall be sent to a facility where they are incinerated or otherwise rendered nonhazardous. (d) Disposable waste shall be placed in easily cleanable, closed containers provided with tightfitting lids to prevent leakage or spillage. (e) Waste containers shall be kept closed when not in use. (f) Disposable waste shall be handled, stored, and disposed of to minimize direct exposure of personnel to waste materials. (g) The waste containers shall be located as near as feasible to the area of use. These containers shall not be overfilled. Sec. 18-33. - Personnel. (a) Artists performing the tattoo operation shall obtain current certification in emergency first-aid, sterilization, and sanitary procedures. (b) The artist must obtain a physical examination by a licensed physician within 12 months prior to employment or initial application for permit and repeated annually. The examination must be sufficiently comprehensive to assure that the artist is free of communicable diseases. To assure the artist is free of communicable diseases the following lab tests must be done at his expense: Hepatitis B and C, syphilis, HIV, and PPD and must be repeated annually. Proof of said exam must be furnished to the health department. (c) The owner must maintain a file on all employees who perform tattoo procedures, which will be available for inspection and includes the following: (1) Report of physical examination, including laboratory test results. (2) Evidence of emergency first-aid, sterilization, and sanitation certification. Sec. 18-34. - Client files. (a) For each client, proper records of tattoos administered shall be maintained by the studio. (b) Records of each client shall be prepared prior to the procedure being performed and shall reflect the client's name and signature, address, proof of age, date tattooed, design, its location and name of the artist. (c) A statement of informed consent by the individual receiving the tattoo must be maintained on file for a period of three years. (d) A statement by the client attesting that he is not under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs shall be on file. (e) A copy of procedures signed by the client advising them of proper subsequent care of the tattoo shall be maintained on file for a period of three years. (f) A copy of instructions signed by the client informing them of the risks involved and possible complications that might result from the tattoo procedure must be maintained on file for a period of three years. Sec. 18-35. - Application for permit. (a) The owner of each tattoo studio shall submit to the county health department annually an application for a permit to operate a tattoo studio under these rules and regulations. No tattoo studio shall be operated and no tattooing performed without a valid permit which is current under these rules and regulations. (b) The application for a permit shall be made on forms provided by the health department. (c) Each application for a permit shall be accompanied by a floor sketch of the tattoo studio showing windows, doors, room measurements, chairs, tables and equipment placement for clients and staff. (d) A listing of the names of all staff including the owner who will be working in the studio shall be included with the application for a permit. This listing shall include the full name, current address and home phone number of each staff person. (e) The ownership of the studio shall be fully disclosed in its application for a permit. (f) Proof of compliance with zoning and other local requirements regarding the proper location and establishment of tattoo studios shall be furnished by the applicant prior to the issuance of a permit. (g) The applicant shall certify in its application the name of employees or artists who are designated as being responsible for complying with the rules and policies adopted by the owner for the operation of the studio. (h) The applicant must consent for the county health department to obtain his criminal history record information. (i) The applicant shall attach to his application a copy of a written statement of policies and procedures outlining the responsibilities of management to ensure compliance with these rules and regulations. (j) To offset the costs of application processing and inspection, a nonrefundable fee in the amount provided in the county fee schedule shall accompany each application for an original or a renewed license. Sec. 18-36. - Permit. (a) The owner of each tattoo studio shall obtain a valid permit from the health department prior to beginning operation and annually thereafter. To be eligible for a permit the studio must be in compliance with these rules and regulations. (b) The permit shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises. (c) The permit is not transferable from one studio to another or from one owner to the other. Transfer of ownership shall also mean the transfer of a majority of the stock of a corporation, if the owner is a corporation. (d) A permit shall no longer be valid and shall be returned to the county when the studio ceases to operate, is moved to another location, the ownership changes, or the permit is suspended or revoked. (e) A studio which fails to comply with these rules and regulations shall be subject to the sanctions available to the health department pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1 et seq. including but not limited to denial or revocation of its permit by the county. Sec. 18-37. - Inspections. (a) The studio and its records shall be available for review and examination by properly identified representatives of the county during business hours. (b) A copy of the inspection report shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the premises and also shall be available for public inspection at the health department. Sec. 18-38. - Enforcement and penalties. (a) Enforcement of these rules and regulations shall be in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1 et seq. (b) No tattoo studio shall be operated without a permit. Failure or refusal to file an application for a permit shall constitute a violation of O.C.G.A. § 31-40-1 et seq. Any person who fails or refuses to file an application shall be subject to the penalties provided by law including, but not limited to, an order to cease and desist operating a tattoo studio. (c) The health department may refuse to grant a permit for the operation of any tattoo studio which does not fulfill the minimum requirements of these rules and regulations and may revoke a permit which has been issued and invoke other sanctions if a studio violates any of these rules and regulations. Before any order is entered refusing a permit applied for of revoking a permit, the applicant or permit holder shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing as provided in O.C.G.A. § 31-5-1 et seq. (d) The health department is empowered to institute appropriate proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction for the purpose of enjoining violation of any applicable provision of O.C.G.A. § 31-1-1 et seq., or of these rules and regulations. Secs. 18-39—18-64. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SMOKING
Sec. 18-65. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: County facilities, facilities of the county mean all facilities owned and/or occupied by the county and its agents and employees. Smoke or smoking means any act of burning any tobacco product of any kind in a cigarette, cigar or pipe. Sec. 18-66. - Purpose. This article has been enacted and is designed for the purpose of protecting public health and welfare by prohibiting smoking in public places and places of employment and for other purposes. Sec. 18-67. - Smoking in county facilities. There shall be no smoking in any facility owed by the county or occupied by county officials or employees. Sec. 18-68. - Signs to be posted. "No Smoking" signs shall be placed conspicuously in county facilities to serve as a directive to employees and the general public. O.C.G.A. § 16-12-2 prohibits smoking in areas clearly marked by "No Smoking" signs. Sec. 18-69. - Enforcement. This article shall be enforced by any authorized law enforcement officer of the county or the county administrator. Sec. 18-70. - Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this article shall be punished by a fine of not less than $10.00 or more than $100.00.

div.head: Chapter 20 - LAND USE AND DEVELOPMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Zoning procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-66-1 et seq.; zoning proposal review procedures, O.C.G.A. § 36-67-1 et seq.; conflict of interest in zoning actions, O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.; county and municipal planning, O.C.G.A. § 36-70-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 20-1. - Authority. This chapter is adopted pursuant to the authority granted by article IX, section II, paragraph IV, of the Georgia Constitution. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. I, § 1-1) Sec. 20-2. - Jurisdiction. The provisions of this chapter shall govern the use of all land and development within the unincorporated areas of the county. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. I, § 1-2) Sec. 20-3. - Purpose and intent. The intent of this chapter is for the purpose of promoting the health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity, and general welfare of the present and future inhabitants of the county. In furtherance of this general intent, the regulation of land use and development by the county is adopted for the following purposes: (1) To lessen congestion in the streets; (2) To secure safety from fire, panic and other dangers; (3) To promote the health and the general welfare; (4) To provide adequate light and air; (5) To provide adequate water, sewerage and surface drainage; (6) To prevent overcrowding of the land; (7) To assure the timely provision of required streets, utilities, other facilities and services to new land development; (8) To encourage land development in an orderly, serviceable and equitable manner; (9) To protect property against blight and depreciation; (10) To encourage the most appropriate use of land and structures; and (11) To assure the adequate provision of safe and convenient traffic access and circulation, both vehicular and pedestrian, in and through new land developments. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. I, § 1-4) Sec. 20-4. - Interpretation. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this chapter shall be considered minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, morals, convenience, order, prosperity and general welfare of the community. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-1.2) Sec. 20-5. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Accessory use means a use or structure on the same lot with, and of a nature customarily incidental and subordinate to, the principal use or structure. Adult bookstore means an establishment having as a substantial or significant portion of its stock books, magazines, publications, tapes or films that are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matters depicting, describing or relating to sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. Adult entertainment establishment means a regulated use which contains, or is used for commercial entertainment where the patron directly or indirectly is charged a fee to engage in personal contact with or to allow personal contact by employees, devices, equipment or by personnel provided by the establishment; or where the patron views a series of dance routines, strip performances or other gyrational choreography provided by the establishment which appeals to the prurient interest of the patron. Adult theater means a regulated use for the viewing of performances or activities by others, whether such performances are in the form of live shows, motion pictures, slide shows or other forms of photographic or visual display, which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matters depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined herein, or an establishment with a segment or section devoted to the sale or display of such material. Adult use means any building or structure or portion of any building or structure used or proposed to be used for an adult bookstore, adult entertainment establishment or adult theater. Agricultural pursuit means all agricultural pursuits including field crop farming, forestry, dairying, pasturage, poultry husbandry, plant nursery and the necessary accessory uses; provided, however, that the raising of hogs, pigs or other livestock fed from garbage or offal, or other agricultural uses that produce noxious odors are excluded from this definition. Alley means a platted service way providing a secondary means of access to abutting property. Amendment means any repeal, modification or addition to a regulation; any new regulation; any change in the numbers, shape, boundary or area of a district, or any repeal or abolition of any map, part thereof, or addition thereto. Antenna means equipment designed to transmit or receive electronic signals. Apartment means a room or suite of one or more rooms which is designed or intended for occupancy by, or which is occupied by, one family doing its own cooking therein, or by one person doing his own cooking therein. Appeal means a request for a review of the interpretation of any provisions of this chapter. Applicant means the owner of land submitting an application for development. Automobile parking lot, commercial, or automobile parking garage, commercial, means a lot or building or portion thereof, other than an automobile sales lot, held out or used for the storage or parking of six or more motor vehicles for a consideration where service or repair facilities are not permitted. Such parking lot or garage shall not be considered an accessory use nor shall it be used for the storage of dismantled or wrecked motor vehicles or parts thereof or of junk. Automobile service station or automobile service center. (1) The term "automobile service station" or "automobile service center" means a building and premises where gasoline, oil, grease, batteries, tire and automobile accessories may be supplied and dispensed at retail, and where, in addition, the following services may be rendered and sales made, and no other: a. Sale and servicing of spark plug, batteries and distributors and distribution parts; b. Tire servicing and repair, but not recapping or regrooving; c. Replacement of muffler and tailpipes, water hoses, fan belts, brake fluid, light bulbs, fuses, floor mats, seat covers, windshield wipers and wiper blades, grease retainers, wheel bearings, mirrors, and the like; d. Radiator cleaning and flushing; e. Washing and polishing and sale of automotive washing and polishing materials; f. Greasing and lubrication; g. Providing and repairing fuel pumps, oil pumps and lines; h. Emergency wiring repairs; i. Minor servicing and repair of carburetors; j. Adjusting and repairing brakes; k. Minor motor adjustments not involving removal of the head or crankcase or racing the motor; l. Sales of cold drinks, packaged foods, tobacco and similar convenience goods for station customers as accessory and incidental to the principal operation; and m. Provision of road maps and other informational material to customers; n. Provision of restroom facilities. (2) Uses permissible at a service station do not include: a. Major mechanical and body work; b. Straightening of body parts; c. Painting; d. Welding; e. Storage of automobiles not in operating condition; or f. Other work involving noise, glare, fumes, smoke or other characteristics to an extent greater than normally found in automobile service stations or centers. (3) An automobile service station or center is not a repair garage or a body shop. Automobile wrecking means the dismantling, storage, sale or dumping of used motor vehicles, trailers or parts thereof. Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year, also known as the 100-year flood. Bed and breakfast means an owner-occupied house or portion thereof, where short-term (no more than a week at a time) lodging rooms and meals are provided with no more than five guestrooms available for accommodations and breakfast service in such an establishment at any one time. Block means a tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad right-of-ways, shorelines of waterways, or boundary lines of municipalities or counties. Bond means any form of security including a cash deposit, surety bond, or instrument of credit in an amount and form satisfactory to the governing authority. All bonds shall be approved by the governing authority wherever a bond is required by these regulations. Buffer means an opaque or semi-opaque screen consisting of a wall, fence, landscaped earth berm, planted vegetation or existing vegetation, intended to separate and partially obstruct the view of two adjacent incompatible land uses or properties from one another. Buildable area of lot means the area of a lot within the building setback lines as set by this chapter within which a structure may be erected. Building means any structure built for the support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, chattel, or movable property of any kind, and includes any structure. The term "building" includes the term "structure." Building area means the total areas taken on a horizontal plane at the main grade level of the principal building and all accessory buildings, exclusive of uncovered porches, terraces and steps. Building area of a lot means that portion of a lot bounded by the required rear, side and front building setback lines. Building height means the vertical distance from the established average sidewalk grade, street grade or finished grade at the building lines, whichever is the highest, to the highest point of the building. Building inspector means the authorized building inspector for the county. Building line means the line beyond which a building shall not extend as determined by front, side, and rear yards defined herein. Building, main, means a building in which is conducted the principle use of the lot on which it is situated. In any residential district, any dwelling shall be deemed to be a main building on the lot on which it is situated. Building permit means a written permit issued by the county zoning administrator or building inspector. Building setback, front, means the minimum allowable distance between the centerline of an abutting street, or an official future street, and the front of a building or structure on a lot. The front setback distance applies to the full width of the lot and is parallel to or concentric with the street centerline. Building setback line means a line delineating the minimum allowable distance between the property line and a building on a lot within which no building or other structures shall be placed. Building setback, rear, means the minimum allowable distance between the rear property line and a building or structure on a lot. The rear setback applies to and extends the full width of the lot. Building setback, side, means the minimum allowable distance between the side property line and a building or structure on a lot. The side setback applies to and extends the full depth of the lot. Building site means the ground area of a building or buildings together with all open spaces surrounded by said building or buildings. Care home means a rest home, nursing home, convalescent home, home for the aged or similar use established and operated to provide lodging and meals or domiciliary care for aged, infirm, chronically ill or convalescent persons. Centerline means the line determined as such by the official authority having jurisdiction over the street; otherwise it shall be the succession of midpoints between the identifiable limits of any improvements on the ground or of any easement. Child care center, family, means a private residence operated by any person who receives for pay therein for supervision and care fewer than 24 hours a day, without transfer of legal custody, at least three but not more than six children under 18 years of age who are not related to such persons and whose parents or guardians are not residents in the same private residence. Child care center, group, means any place operated by any person or group wherein for pay are received not less than seven nor more than 18 children under 18 years of age for care and supervision less than 24 hours a day. Clinic means an establishment where medical or dental patients, who are not lodged overnight, are admitted for examination or treatment. Club, church or fraternal organization means buildings and facilities owned or operated by a corporation, association, person or persons for a social, educational, religious or recreational purpose, but not primarily for profit or to render a service which is customarily a business. Commercial use means any use involving in part or in whole, the storage of merchandise, sale of merchandise, materials or services, but not including home occupations, as defined in this section. Communications tower means a tower of any size located on a nonresidential site, which supports communication equipment (transmission or receiving) utilized by commercial, government, or other public and quasi-public users. The term "communications tower" does not include private home use or satellite dishes and television antennas or amateur radio operators' antennas as licensed by the Federal Communications Commission, and excluding those used exclusively for dispatch communications. Comprehensive plan means the comprehensive land use plan for the county adopted by the board of commissioners under O.C.G.A. § 36-70-3. Conditional use means a use permitted in a particular zoning district only upon showing that such use in a specified location will comply with all conditions and standards for the location or operation of such use as specified in this chapter and authorized by the county planning and zoning board. Convenience establishment means a convenience gas station or a convenience store as defined in this section. Convenience gas station means a building and premises where gasoline and oil may be dispensed at retail. Uses permissible also include the sale of cold drinks, package foods, tobacco and similar convenience goods for station customers. Convenience store means a one-story, retail store that is designed and stocked to sell primarily food, beverages, household supplies and other convenience goods on a small-scale basis. Customary home occupation means a business, profession, occupation, or trade conducted for gain or support by any occupant of a dwelling and located entirely within a residential building or a structure accessory thereto, which use is accessory, incidental, and secondary to the use of the building for dwelling purposes and does not change the essential residential character or appearance of such building. Dedicated to public use means land or improvements that have been deeded to and accepted by the county for public use and maintenance. Developer means a person who is responsible for any undertaking that requires a building permit, conditional use permit or sign permit. Director and engineer include the term "designee." Drive-in means a retail or service enterprise oriented to automobile driving patrons wherein service is provided to the consumer on the outside or inside of the principal building. The term "drive-in" includes drive-in restaurants and dairy bars, theaters, banks, laundries, food stores or car washes. Dwelling means any building or portion thereof, which is designed or used exclusively for permanent living quarters for one or more persons. Dwelling, multifamily, means a building designed for and used as a residence for three or more families, and consisting of three or more separate dwelling units. Dwelling, single-family, means a structure including a site-built, modular or manufactured home that contains one dwelling unit designed for residential use that is surrounded by open space on the same lot. All single-family dwellings shall meet the appearance standards as provided in this chapter. A mobile home is not a single-family dwelling. Dwelling, townhouse, means one of a series of three or more attached one-family dwelling units on separate lots that may or may not have a common roof, do not have a common exterior wall, and are separated from each other by fire-resistive party wall partitions extending at least from the lowest floor level to the roof. Dwelling, two-family, means a building containing not more than two housekeeping units, and designed or used to house not more than two families, living independently of each other. Dwelling unit means any building or portion thereof, providing complete living facilities for one family. Easement means a strip of land on which a property owner has granted a person, corporation or governing authority the right to use such land for a specific purpose. Escrow means a deposit of cash with the governing authority or escrow agent to secure the promise to perform some act. Evidence means any testimony, document or other items which may be admissible, pursuant to state law in any trial or hearing conducted in any court of this state. Family means one or more persons occupying a single dwelling unit; provided that, unless all members are related by blood, legal adoption or marriage, the dwelling unit shall contain no more than five persons; and further provided that domestic servants employed on the premises may be housed on the premises. Family, immediate, means one or more persons, or parents, with their direct lineal descendents and adopted children, living together in the whole or part of a dwelling, comprising a single housekeeping unit. Filling station means any building or premises used solely for the storing, dispensing, servicing, sale or offering for sale at retail of any automobile fuels and lubricants or automobile accessories but not including major automobile repairing. Floodplain means any land area susceptible to be inundated by water from the base flood. As used in this chapter, the term "floodplain" refers to that area designated as subject to flooding from the base flood (100-year flood) on the flood boundary and floodway map prepared by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. (See Base flood. ) Frontage means that side of a lot abutting on a street or way ordinarily regarded as the front of the lot, but it shall not be considered as the ordinary side of a corner lot. Frontage, double, means a lot, tract or parcel of land which abuts the right-of-way of more than one public street. Frontage, street, means all the property on one side of a street between two intersecting streets (crossing or terminating), or if the street is dead ended, then all of the property abutting on one side between an intersecting street and the dead end street. Garage means a building used for the storage or housing of motor-driven vehicles. Garage, private, means a garage intended for and owned or used by, the members of families resident upon the premises, provided that not more than one-half of the garage space may be rented for private vehicles owned or used by persons not resident on the premises, except that all the space in a garage of one- or two-car capacity may be so rented. Such a garage shall not include those used by more than one commercial vehicle per family resident on the premises, and no such commercial vehicle shall exceed two-ton capacity nor shall such garage provide for the repair or equipping of such vehicles. Garage, storage, means a garage used primarily for storage of vehicles. Grade means the slope of a road, street, or other public way, specific in percentage terms from the horizontal. Gross floor area (GFA) means the total area of a building measured by taking the outside dimensions of the building at each floor level intended for occupancy or storage. Gross living area (GLA) means the total area of finished, above-grade residential space excluding unheated areas such as porches and balconies; the standard measure for determining the amount of space in residential properties. Health department means the county health department. Hotel means any building which contains sleeping rooms for the more or less temporary occupancy of individuals who are lodged with or without meals, with no provision made for any cooking in any individual room or suite. Individual sewage disposal system means a septic tank, seepage tile sewage disposal system, or any other sewage treatment device. Industrial street or boulevard means a street of some continuity used primarily by all forms of commercial or industrial vehicular traffic and used for intercommunication between commercial areas and residential areas and industrial districts or between industrial districts. Industrialized building, modular home means a factory fabricated transportable building consisting of units designed for incorporation into a permanent structure at a building site on a permanent foundation to be used for residential purposes. A modular home shall be certified by the manufacturer to meet the approval of the state building administration board (SBAB) to meet the same requirements as a site-built home within the county. An industrialized building is a single-family dwelling and its placement in a residential district must meet or exceed the appearance standards as provided in section 20-734. Junkyard or salvage yard means a lot, land or structure or part thereof, used primarily for the collecting, storage or sale of wastepaper, rags, scrap metal or other discarded material; and for the collecting, dismantling, storage, salvage of machinery or vehicles not in running condition, or for the sale of parts thereof. Kennel means a commercial operation that provides food and shelter and care of animals for purposes not primarily related to medical care or that engages in the breeding of animals for sale. A kennel may or may not be run by or associated with a veterinarian. Lane means a public thoroughfare which ordinarily affords only a secondary means of access to abutting property and which is not more than 25 feet wide. Loading and unloading area means that portion of the vehicle accommodation area used to satisfy the screening requirements of this chapter. Lot means a parcel of land occupied or to be occupied by one or more buildings and its accessory buildings with such open and parking spaces as are required by the provisions of these regulations and having its frontage upon a public street or streets or with access from a public street or highway over a private way. The term "lot" includes the term "plot" or "parcel." Lot area means the total horizontal ground area inside lot lines. Lot, corner, means a lot which abuts on two or more streets or roads, at their intersection, or upon a curved street, provided that the two sides of the lot, or the tangents to the curve of the street line at its starting points at or within the side lines of the lot, intersect to form an interior angle of not more than 135 degrees. Lot coverage means the computed ground area occupied by buildings within a lot. Lot depth means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines measured in the general direction of the side lines of the lot. Lot, double frontage, means a lot having frontage on two streets as distinguished from a corner lot. (See Lot, corner. ) Lot, flag, means a lot not meeting minimum frontage requirements and where access to the public road is by a narrow, private right-of-way or driveway. No flag lots shall be created within the unincorporated area of the county. Lot frontage means the distance for which the front property line and street line coincide. Lot improvement means any building, structure, place, work of art or other object, or improvement of the land on which they are situated, constituting a physical betterment of real property, or any part of such betterment. Lot, interior, means a lot other than a corner lot. Lot line, front, means the front lot line of an interior lot separating the lot from the fronting street right-of-way. The front lot line of a corner lot shall be the lot line upon which the principal building entrance will front. Lot line, rear, means the rear lot line boundary opposite and more or less parallel to the front lot line. The rear lot line of an irregular or triangular lot shall be, for the purpose of this chapter, a line not less than ten feet long, lying wholly within the lot, and parallel to and the farthest distance from the front lot line. Lot line, side, means a side lot boundary line that is not a front lot line or a rear lot line. A side lot line separating a lot from a street line is an exterior side lot line. Any other side lot line is an interior side lot line. Lot of record means a lot or parcel of land whose existence, location, and dimensions have been recorded in the office of the clerk of the county's superior court. Lot width means the width of the lot measured at the setback line. Major road plan means any legally adopted plan for the future development or classification of major roads in the county. Manufactured home means a structure defined by and constructed in accordance with the federal Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974 as amended 42 USC 5401 et seq., adopted June 15, 1976. The definition is as follows: Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this paragraph except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development complying with the standards established under this title. Map or zoning map means the official county zoning map. Master sewerage plan means the long-range master plan for the development of public sewerage systems as adopted by the board of commissioners. Mobile home, as provided in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-160, means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or 40 body feet or more in length or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure that meets all the requirements of this definition except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the secretary of housing and urban development and complies with the standards established under the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Standards Act of 1974, 42 USC 5401 et seq. Modular home. See Industrialized building. Motel means any building containing sleeping rooms for more or less temporary occupancy of individuals who are lodged with or without meals and where the design favors a direct vehicular approach to each sleeping or living room. Any building or structure exceeding two stories in height shall be classified as a hotel rather than a motel. Natural grade means the elevation of the ground adjoining the building. Neighborhood shopping center means a shopping center which consists entirely or primarily of convenient goods outlets with a supermarket as anchoring tenant. Neighborhood shopping centers generally do not have enclosed air-conditioned malls, elaborate landscaping and similar amenities typical of larger shopping centers. Nonconforming lot means a lot existing at the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived (and not created for the purposes of evading the restrictions of this chapter) that does not meet the minimum area requirements of the district in which the lot is located. Nonconforming use means any building, structure or use of land existing at the time of enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived which does not comply with or conform to the provisions of the zoning district in which it is located. Nonconforming signs shall be governed by the provisions of article XIII, regarding nonconforming uses, and chapter 30, regarding signs. Off-site means any premises not located within the area of the property to be subdivided whether or not in the same ownership of the applicant for subdivision approval. Off-street loading space means the area required to load or unload goods or other materials plus the necessary driveways and maneuvering areas. Off-street parking space means the area required to park one automobile plus the necessary driveways and maneuvering areas. On-site disposal means the disposal of sewage from an individual use into the ground, a septic tank, or elsewhere except into a public or private sewerage system. Open space means a parcel or parcels of land or an area of water or a combination of both land and water within the designated development and designed and intended for the use and enjoyment of residents of the development or for the general public, not including streets or off-street parking areas. Open space shall be substantially free of structures, but may contain such improvements as are in the plans as finally approved and are appropriate for the benefit of residents of the development. Parcel means a general term including all plots of land shown with separate identification on the official tax appraisal maps. Parcels may or may not be lots, depending upon whether or not such parcels are created as herein provided. Parking lot means a parcel of land devoted to unenclosed parking spaces which may include partially enclosed one-story buildings and where a charge is made for storage or parking of vehicles. Permitted use means a use by right which is specifically authorized in a particular zoning district. Personal care means protective care and watchful oversight of a resident who needs a watchful environment but who does not have an illness, injury or disability which requires chronic or convalescent care including medical and nursing services. The term "protective care and watchful oversight" includes but is not limited to a daily awareness by the care provider of the resident's functioning, his whereabouts, the making and reminding a resident of appointments for medical checkups, the ability and readiness to intervene if a crisis arises for a resident, supervision in areas of nutrition and medication, and actual provision of transient medical care, with a 24-hour responsibility for the well-being of the resident. Personal care home means a building occupied as a permanent primary residence and also occupied by up to five unrelated ambulatory adults who reside there temporarily or long-term and receive services, including room, meals and personal care from the permanent occupants. The term "personal care home" does not include buildings which are devoted to independent living units which include kitchen facilities in which residents have the option of preparing and serving some or all their own meals or boarding facilities which do not provide personal care. Planned center, office, commercial , or industrial, means a group of three or more retail stores, service establishments, offices, industries or any other businesses planned to serve the public, which is in common ownership or condominium ownership. Planned unit development means any planned concentration which provides for innovative concepts in large-scale residential, commercial, or industrial development which enables economy in capital expenditures or utilities and streets and in subsequent maintenance. Planning and zoning board means the county planning and zoning board. Plat, final, means the plat submitted to the planning and zoning board for final approval and, subsequently, to be recorded with the county clerk of the superior court. Plat of record means an abbreviated version of the final plat of a subdivision that is prepared as required by these regulations for filing, and is so filed, with the clerk of the superior court. Plat, preliminary, means the plat or layout of a proposed subdivision submitted to the planning and zoning board for approval prior to submission of the final plat. Principal building means a building in which is conducted the principal use of the lot or tract of land on which such building is located. Principal use means the primary use of land or structures as distinguished from a conditional use or accessory use. Private sewerage means a sanitary sewerage system for the collection of waterborne wastes complete with a sewage treatment plant or stabilization pond which is owned and operated by a person or corporation other than a public authority or agency. Public hearing means a meeting announced and advertised in advance and open to the public, with the public given an opportunity to talk and participate. Public improvement means any drainage ditch, roadway, parkway, sidewalk, pedestrian way, tree, lawn, off-street parking area, lot improvement, or other facility for which the local government may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation, or which may affect an improvement for which local government responsibility is established. Public notice means a notice published once in a newspaper of general circulation in the country at least 15 days prior to a public hearing setting forth the time, place and purpose of said public hearing concerning: (1) Proposed changes or amendments to this chapter including the maps thereto; (2) Appeals, variances or conditional use permits; or (3) Review of a preliminary plat. Public sewerage means a sanitary sewerage system for the collection of waterborne wastes complete with a sewage treatment plant or stabilization pond which is owned and operated by a public authority or agency. Public utilities means water, gas, sanitary and storm sewer, electrical, and communication lines and facilities, and natural or improved drainage facilities. Registered land surveyor means a land surveyor properly licensed and registered in this state. Right-of-way line means a strip of land occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, crosswalk, railroad, road, electric transmission line, oil or gas pipeline, water main, storm or sanitary sewer main, shade trees, or for another special use, and owned by a county or municipality. Rural street or rural road means a street supplementary to the major street system which primarily serves agricultural areas or other lands not subdivided for residential use. Screening means either: (1) A strip of at least ten feet wide, densely planted (or having equivalent natural growth) with shrubs or trees at least four feet high at the time of planting, of a type that will form a yearround dense screen at least six feet high; or (2) An opaque wall or barrier or uniformly painted fence at least six feet high. Setback means the required distance between a structure and the lot lines on the lot in which the structure is located. Lot lines can be the property lines or the edge of a street right-of-way. Shoulder means that portion of a roadway between the outer edge of the paved surface or the curb to the inside edge of the ditch or gutter or original ground surface. Sidewalk means that portion of a street or road right-of-way available exclusively for pedestrian traffic. Sketch plat or site plan means a generalized map prepared by the developer that shows the development concept. Its purpose is to serve as a basis for discussion without either the planning and zoning board or the developer making commitments. Street means a right-of-way for vehicular traffic whether designated a street, highway, thoroughfare, parkway, road, avenue, drive, expressway, freeway, boulevard, lane, place, circle, alley, or otherwise. Various types of streets may be defined as follows: Arterial street means a public way which is used primarily for fast and heavy traffic flow; is of considerable continuity; and is used as a traffic artery for intercommunication among large areas. Collector street means a major street used for traffic of moderate speed and high peak volumes between land service streets and arteries or serving as principal entrance streets or primary circulation routes within a subdivision, neighborhood or other limited area. Cul-de-sac means a local street with only one outlet, closed and terminated by a vehicular turnaround. It shall not extend to more than 700 feet in length and shall be provided with a turnaround having a roadway diameter of at least 80 feet and a right-of-way diameter of at least 100 feet. Local street means a street used primarily in residential subdivisions for access to abutting properties as opposed to the collection and dispersion of traffic. Marginal access street means a street which is parallel or adjacent to an arterial street or highway and which provides access to abutting properties and protection from through traffic. Private street means private access from a public road to land abutting on the right-of-way thereof; a street that has not been accepted by the county. Street, county, means a street which is owned or maintained by the county. Street grade means the grade of the curb or centerline of a street measured at any point along the street. Street width means the shortest distance between the lines delineating the right-of-way of a street. Structural alterations means any change in the supporting members of a building or structure, such as bearing walls, columns, beams, girders, floor joists or roof joists, or in the exterior walls. Structure means anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on or in the ground, or attached to something having a fixed location on the ground. Structures include, but are not limited to the following: site-built buildings, industrialized buildings, manufactured homes, billboards, swimming pools, advertising signs, satellite dishes and fall-out shelters. Subdivider means any person, firm or corporation, or the authorized agent of such person, firm or corporation, having such a proprietary interest in the land to be subdivided so as to have authority to authorize the maintenance of proceedings to subdivide such land under these regulations. Subdivision means the division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, plats, sites or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or of building development for purposes other than agricultural. It includes all such subdivision of land involving new streets or a change in existing streets and includes resubdivision. Subdivision improvement agreement means a contract entered into by the applicant and the planning and zoning board on behalf of the county by which the applicant promises to complete the required public improvements within the subdivision within a specified time period following final subdivision plat approval. Surveyor means a registered, practicing surveyor, licensed by the State of Georgia. Tower means any structure whose principal function is to support an antenna. Tract means a lot. The term "tract' is used interchangeably with the term lot, particularly in the context of subdivisions, where one tract is subdivided into several lots. Travel trailer means a vehicular portable structure built on a chassis, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel and recreational purposes, and having a body width not exceeding eight feet. Travel trailer park means any plot or tract of land on which two or more travel trailers are located or intended to be located for purposes of temporary occupancy. Tree means any object of natural growth. Use means the purpose for which land or a building or other structure is designed, arranged or intended for which it is or may be occupied or maintained. Used or occupied , as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the term "intended," "arranged," or "designed to be used or occupied." Utility facilities means any above-ground structures or facilities other than buildings, unless such buildings are used as storage incidental to the operation of such structures or facilities, owned by a governmental entity, a nonprofit organization, a corporation, or any entity defined as a public utility for any purpose by the appropriate provision of state law and used in connection with the production, generation, transmission, delivery, collection, or storage of water, sewage, electricity, gas, oil, or electronic signals. Variance means an alteration or relaxation of the terms of these regulations where such alteration will not be contrary to the public interest, convenience and welfare; where owing to conditions peculiar to the property over which the applicant for a variance has no control, a literal enforcement of these regulations would create unnecessary and undue hardship. Yard means an unoccupied area of a lot, open and unobstructed from the ground to the sky, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. Yard, front, means an open space extending the full width of a lot and of a depth measured horizontally at right angles from the front lot line to the front of the structure. Yard, rear, means an open space extending the full width of a lot and of a depth measured horizontally at right angles from the rear lot line to the rear of the structure. Yard, side, means an open space extending along the side line of a lot between the front yard and the rear yard and of a width measured horizontally at right angles from the side lot line to the side of the structure. Zoning administrator means the county tax assessor or any other individual or agency designated by the board of commissioners to administer this chapter. Zoning change means an action by the board of commissioners causing a change in the boundary of a zoning district so as to change the zoning designation on a property or a portion of a property, or cause the establishment of a conditional use on a property. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. II, §§ 2-1, 2-2) Sec. 20-6. - Adoption of comprehensive plan. The board of commissioners has adopted the Jefferson County Joint Comprehensive Plan, 2009, a copy of which is available in the office of the city clerk. (Res. of 5-3-2010) Secs. 20-7—20-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 20-31. - Required disclosures. (a) O.C.G.A. title 36, ch. 67A (O.C.G.A. § 36-67A-1 et seq.) requires disclosure of financial interests by all government officials, including board of commissioners members and planning and zoning board members, who will consider a rezoning action. It also requires disclosure of campaign contributions or gifts by the rezoning applicant or his attorney. (b) All government officials, including board of commissioners members and planning and zoning board members, are required to disclose in writing any ownership interest they have or any family members have in real property made the subject of a rezoning request. Additionally, these officials are required to disclose in writing any financial interest of ten percent or more in any business entity which has an ownership interest in the property to be considered. (c) An applicant for a rezoning and his attorney must disclose all campaign contributions or gifts aggregating $250.00 or more that were made within two years of the filing of the application for rezoning. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. I, § 1-5) Sec. 20-32. - Complaints regarding violations. Whenever a violation of this chapter occurs, or is alleged to have occurred, any person may file a written complaint. Such complaint stating fully the causes and basis thereof shall be filed with the zoning administrator. He shall record properly such complaint, immediately investigate and take action thereon as provided by this chapter. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-8) Sec. 20-33. - Judicial review. Any party aggrieved because of the alleged error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the planning and zoning board, the board of commissioners, or any other party in the enforcement of this chapter, may take an appeal to the county superior court. The appeal to the superior court shall be the same as an appeal to the superior court from any decision made by the court as specified in O.C.G.A. title 15, ch. 6, art. 2 (O.C.G.A. § 15-6-50 et seq.); provided, however, that said appeal must be filed within 30 days from the date of the decision of the planning and zoning board, the board of commissioners or of any official charged with the enforcement of any order, requirement or decision in connection therewith; and upon failure to file said appeal within 30 days, said decision of the board of commissioners or planning and zoning board shall be final. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-9) Sec. 20-34. - Penalties for violation. (a) Any person found in violation of any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than $500.00 per violation or imprisoned in the county jail for not more than 60 days, or both, and in addition shall pay the cost of such action. Each offense shall constitute a separate offense for each day such violation continues. (b) The county, through its attorney or other official designated by the governing authority of the county, may, in addition to other remedies, institute an injunction, mandamus or other appropriate action or proceeding to enforce the provisions of this chapter. (c) Any building erected in violation of this chapter shall be deemed an unlawful structure, and the building inspector, county attorney, or other official designated by governing authority of the county may bring appropriate action to enjoin such erection or cause it to be vacated or removed. (d) To enforce the provisions of this chapter, when a violation has occurred, a citation and summons may be issued to the alleged violator, requiring him to appear in the county magistrate court or state court on a day and time certain to answer the charges contained herein. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-7) Sec. 20-35. - Board of commissioners. The board of commissioners shall hear and make decisions concerning: (1) Proposed amendments to this chapter; (2) Adoption and amendment to the zoning map and the text of this chapter; and (3) Approval, disapproval or other action on all requests for zoning changes as provided in this chapter. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. III, § 3-2) Sec. 20-36. - Zoning administrator or other designated county official. (a) The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by the zoning administrator or other designated county official. This official shall have the right to enter upon any premises for the purpose of making inspections of buildings or premises necessary to carry out his duties in the enforcement of this chapter. In addition, he shall issue all building permits and make and maintain records thereof, issue all certificates of occupancy and make and maintain records thereof, and conduct inspections as prescribed by this chapter and other such inspections as are necessary to ensure compliance with this chapter. (b) Specifically, but without limitation, the zoning administrator shall have the power and duty to provide the following services related to this chapter: (1) Issue and when necessary revoke building permits as specified in this chapter. (2) Issue a certificate of occupancy as required in this chapter. (3) Issue and when necessary revoke a moving permit (building permit) as specified in this chapter. (4) Issue a sign permit as specified in this chapter. (5) Answer all questions of interpretation of the provisions of this chapter. (6) Administer the provisions of this chapter. (7) Meet with a developer, if requested, during a pre-application conference to discuss a development proposal as defined in this chapter. (8) Dispense general information about this chapter to the public upon request. (9) Enforce, in addition to the enforcement authority of other county officials such as the county marshal, the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. III, §§ 3-3, 13-5) Sec. 20-37. - Building inspector. The building inspector shall have duties and responsibilities as assigned by the zoning administrator. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. III, § 3-4) Secs. 20-38—20-62. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PLANNING AND ZONING BOARD
Sec. 20-63. - Established. There shall be a planning and zoning board consisting of five members. The purpose of the planning and zoning board is to provide informal consultation and formal proceedings for owners wishing to appeal a decision of the zoning administrator, or receive a conditional use permit, receive a variance or subdivide land. (Ord. No. 006-95, 4-11-1995; Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. III, § 3-1) Sec. 20-64. - Appointment; term; chairperson. (a) Planning and zoning board members shall be appointed by the board of commissioners. For the purpose of appointing members to the planning and zoning board, the county shall be divided into four districts which shall be coterminous with board of commissioners' districts. An effort shall be made to provide one member of the planning and zoning board from each district. The fifth member shall be appointed from the county at large. The planning and zoning board shall annually elect one of its members as chairperson. (b) The members shall be appointed for overlapping terms of three years. The board of commissioners shall have the right to remove any member of the planning and zoning board for cause. (Ord. No. 006-95, 4-11-1995; Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. III, § 3-1.1) Sec. 20-65. - Meetings. Meetings of the planning and zoning board shall be at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the board may determine. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. III, § 3-1.2) Sec. 20-66. - Powers and duties. The planning and zoning board shall not have the power to amend these regulations, to rezone any land, to declare this chapter or any amendment thereto invalid or to allow any use not permitted by this chapter. The duties of the planning and zoning board shall include, without limitation: (1) Recommending to the board of commissioners changes in this chapter that the planning and zoning board believes are appropriate. (2) Recommending to the board of commissioners approval, disapproval or other action on all requests for zoning changes as provided in this chapter. (3) Reviewing and approving all plats. (4) Reviewing and approving all subdivision developmental plans. (5) Advising the board of commissioners on matters of zoning and land development as it may deem appropriate. (6) Hearing and deciding appeals as specified in this chapter, where it is alleged by the appellant that there is an error in any order, requirement, permit, decision, determination or refusal made by the zoning administrator or other administrative official in the carrying out or enforcement of any provisions of this chapter. (7) Hearing and deciding applications for a conditional use permit as specified in this chapter. (8) Hearing and deciding questions involving interpretation of the zoning map (official map) including district boundary lines and lot lines, as provided in this chapter. (9) Hearing and deciding applications for variances from the development requirements of this chapter, but only in individual cases of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship. (10) Conducting such other business and affairs as may be, from time to time, designated by the board of commissioners. (Ord. No. 006-95, 4-11-1995; Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. III, § 3-1.4) Secs. 20-67—20-90. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - APPEAL PROCEDURE
Sec. 20-91. - When appeal may be taken. The planning and zoning board shall hear and decide appeals where it is alleged by the appellant that there is an error in any order, requirement, permit, decision or refusal made by the zoning administrator or other administrative official in the administration or enforcement of any provisions of this chapter. Such appeals shall be in accordance with this division. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-1) Sec. 20-92. - Time for filing notice of appeal. (a) An appeal to the planning and zoning board may be taken by any person, firm or corporation aggrieved or by any governmental officer, department, board or agency affected by any decision of the zoning administrator or other administrative official with respect to this chapter. (b) Such appeal shall be made within 30 days following notification of the decision appealed from, by filing with the planning and zoning board, a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The zoning administrator shall forthwith transmit to the planning and zoning board all the papers constituting the record upon which the action was taken. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-1.1) Sec. 20-93. - Public hearings. (a) After receiving an application for an appeal, variance, or conditional use, the planning and zoning board shall schedule a public hearing. (b) The application and fee determined by the county for a hearing and decision on requests for an appeal, variance, or conditional use shall be filed with the zoning administrator on forms provided by the county at least 30 days prior to the next scheduled planning and zoning board meeting. Each application shall contain such information as the zoning administrator may require to enable the planning and zoning board to make its decision on an appeal, conditional use, or variance request. (c) The planning and zoning board shall publish once in a newspaper of general circulation in the county a written notice of such public hearing at least 15 days but not more than 45 days prior to the public hearing. The public notice shall indicate the time, place and nature of the appeal, variance or conditional use to be considered by the planning and zoning board. At the hearing any party may appear in person, or by agent, or by attorney. (d) Additionally, at least 15 days before the scheduled public hearing, the zoning administrator shall post in a conspicuous place on the property a sign at least two feet by three feet in size. It shall set forth the time, place and purpose of the public hearing before the planning and zoning board. Acts of vandalism or natural occurrences limiting the effectiveness of notice by a sign posted on the property shall not invalidate any proceedings or action taken under this article. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-4) Sec. 20-94. - Stay of proceedings. An appeal stays all actions by the zoning administrator seeking enforcement of or compliance with the order or decision appealed from, unless the zoning administrator certifies to the planning and zoning board that a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-1.2) Sec. 20-95. - Evidence to be presented at public hearing. The appellant and any public agency or private individual shall be entitled to present evidence on matters before the planning and zoning board at the public hearing as required in this article. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-1.3) Sec. 20-96. - Determination by planning and zoning board. The planning and zoning board, in conformity with this chapter, may modify in whole or in part any order, requirement, or decision of the zoning administrator and to that end shall have the power of the zoning administrator or administrative official from whom the appeal is taken. The planning and zoning board may direct the issuance of a permit. It shall be the duty of the zoning administrator to carry out the decisions of the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-1.4) Secs. 20-97—20-120. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - AMENDMENTS
Sec. 20-121. - Authority; requirements for effectivity. (a) The board of commissioners may from time to time, amend, supplement or change the regulations set forth in this chapter or the boundaries of the zoning districts established on the zoning map. (b) No amendment shall become effective unless it shall have been initiated by either the board of commissioners or the planning and zoning board, the property owners, or an individual who has the owners' power of attorney authorizing him to act, or a request signed by 60 percent of the property owners who hold not less than 60 percent of the affected land. (c) All proposed amendments shall first be submitted to the planning and zoning board, which shall conduct a public hearing and shall make a written recommendation to the board of commissioners. The power to approve and enact an amendment rests solely within the legislative discretion of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-1(a), (b)) Sec. 20-122. - Definitions. As used in this article, the term "amendment" shall mean both a change to the official map and a change to the text of this chapter unless otherwise indicated. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-1(b)) Sec. 20-123. - Application procedure. (a) All proposed amendments shall be initiated by an application with the zoning administrator on forms provided by the county. A standard fee shall be paid with the application in the amount of the advertising costs for the required public hearing. Application for amendment of these regulations may be in the form of a proposal for amendment of the text of regulations or a proposal for amendment of the zoning map. (b) Within 15 days after receiving the application, the zoning administrator shall in writing inform the applicant of the date on which a public hearing will be held to consider the zoning change. (c) No application will be accepted from any person regarding any property that is in violation of this chapter. If the property, at the time of application, which is the subject of an amendment or any other action of the board of commissioners, is found to be in violation of this chapter, then the board of commissioners will not accept or process any application from that applicant until the applicant voluntarily removes or changes the cause of the violation or ceases to be in violation. The applicant must then notify the zoning administrator that he is no longer in violation and obtain a release from the zoning administrator as to the violation. Once released, the board of commissioners will then accept the application for amendment of this chapter. (d) Upon receiving an application for a map amendment and establishing the date of the public hearing concerning the petitioned request, the zoning administrator shall erect in a conspicuous place on the property in question or on the right-of-way of the nearest public road, if the property does not front a public road, a sign giving notice of both the existing zoning district in which the property is located and the requested change and the scheduled date and place for the public hearing. (e) After acceptance of an application for amendment, the zoning administrator shall transmit a copy thereof to the planning and zoning board. The board will study the proposed amendment and determine if it meets the standards as enumerated in this division. (f) Once the public hearing has been conducted in accordance with this division, the planning and zoning board shall make a written recommendation to the board of commissioners stating its approval or disapproval of the requested zoning change. Such recommendation shall be made by the planning and zoning board within 30 days of the public hearing or the requested zoning change shall be deemed to have been recommended for approval by the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-2) Sec. 20-124. - Standards for review. (a) The exercise of the zoning power of the county shall constitute an effort to balance the interest of the community in promoting the public health, safety, morality and general welfare against the right of property owners to the unrestricted use of their property. (b) The factors set forth in this subsection (b) shall be considered by the planning and zoning board when reviewing and making its written recommendation and the board of commissioners when making a decision whether to approve or deny the requested amendment. The following factors are determined to be relevant in balancing the interest in promoting the public health, safety, morality and general welfare against the right to the unrestricted use of the property: (1) Whether the proposed amendment would allow a use that is generally suitable for the site compared to other possible uses and the uses and zoning of adjacent and nearby properties; (2) Whether the proposed amendment would adversely affect the economic value or the uses of adjacent and nearby properties; (3) Whether the property to be affected by the proposed amendment can be used as currently zoned; (4) Whether the proposed amendment, if adopted, would result in a use which would or could cause an excessive or burdensome use of existing streets, schools, sewers, water resources, police and fire protection or other utilities; (5) Whether there are other conditions or transitional patterns affecting the use and development of the property sought to be rezoned, if applicable, which give ground for either approval or disapproval of the proposed amendment. (c) The county planning and zoning board and the board of commissioners shall consider any proposed amendment properly initiated in light of the factors set forth in this section. In evaluating the factors, it shall be the policy of the county to exercise its zoning power in conformity with the policy and intent of the county comprehensive plan insofar as that plan is current in its application to the specific property that is the subject of the proposed amendment. (d) It is further the policy of the county to exercise the zoning power for purposes of assuring the compatibility of use of adjacent and nearby properties and the preservation of the economic value of adjacent and nearby properties while enabling a reasonable use of all property. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-3) Sec. 20-125. - Public hearing. (a) Before making a written recommendation to the board of commissioners, the planning and zoning board shall hold a public hearing. The public hearing shall be conducted at the time and place specified by the planning and zoning board and as set forth in the public notice required in this division. (b) The purpose of the hearing shall be to present to the public the proposed zoning amendment, and to receive comments thereon from the public. (c) The board of commissioners shall consider the proceedings and comments of the hearing on the proposed zoning amendment in making a final decision on whether to approve or deny the amendment application. (d) The planning and zoning board shall prescribe the rules of order for its deliberations on matters with which it is charged under this chapter, and said rules of order shall be consistent with the general requirements and purposes set forth in this chapter and state law concerning conduct of proceedings of public commissions, bodies and governmental units. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-4) Sec. 20-126. - Public notice. At least 15, but not more than 45 days prior to the date set by the planning and zoning board for the hearing, a written notice shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the county setting forth the time, place, and purpose of the hearing. Such notice shall contain a summary of the proposed amendment, if a text amendment, and in the case of a map amendment, the location of the property, its area, name or owner, and the proposed change or classification. The cost of such newspaper notice shall be paid by the applicant for zoning amendment. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-5) Sec. 20-127. - Conduct of hearings. (a) The public hearing shall be convened by the chairperson of the planning and zoning board at the time and place scheduled. (b) The chairperson shall open any hearing with an explanation of the purpose of the hearing and a description of the general rules for the conduct of the hearing. The chairperson or his delegate may describe the authority and role of the planning and zoning board in any zoning decision. (c) The chairperson shall review the procedures for holding the public hearing which shall be as follows: (1) No person may speak until recognized by the chairperson. Upon rising to speak, the person recognized must first state his name and address. (2) The person speaking will be allowed two minutes to express opinions and make points on each separate element of the proposed zoning revisions which he wishes to address; provided, however, that no person shall speak longer than an aggregate of ten minutes. (3) Any remark amounting to an attack on the character or personal integrity of another individual, or a comment not factually supportable, or a comment in the form of an emotional outburst, shall be not germane to the purpose of any hearing and may be ruled out of order. (4) Additional persons will be recognized in accordance with the procedure set forth above for the purpose of addressing additional issues and making additional points, but no speaker shall be allowed to address points which have already been thoroughly discussed. (5) In the case of each petition for amendment to the zoning regulations, the chairperson shall allow the applicant or the agent for the applicant, to speak first and to present the arguments of the applicant in favor of the proposed amendment. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-6) Sec. 20-128. - Official action by the board of commissioners. (a) Once the planning and zoning board submits a written recommendation to the board of commissioners, the board of commissioners, at a regular meeting, may take action approving or rejecting the proposal at that meeting, or the board of commissioners may table the question for consideration at its next regular meeting or a called meeting to be held no later than the next regular meeting. (b) The planning and zoning board's role in any zoning decision shall be advisory only. Any zoning decision shall be made by the board of commissioners who shall either approve or disapprove the proposed zoning amendment. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-7) Sec. 20-129. - Appeal from decision of board of commissioners. Appeals from the decision of the board of commissioners regarding the approval or disapproval of a zoning amendment shall be made in accordance with the judicial review provisions in section 20-33. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-8) Sec. 20-130. - Limitation on reapplication. No application for amendment of the zoning chapter once heard by the planning and zoning board shall be accepted for a rehearing until at least six months shall have passed since written recommendation was made by the planning and zoning board to the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-9) Sec. 20-131. - Withdrawal without prejudice. An application may not be withdrawn or amended by the applicant after the public hearing has been advertised, unless the planning and zoning board by a majority vote allow an application to be withdrawn without prejudice.
