(Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XXI, § 21-10) Secs. 20-132—20-160. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SUBDIVISIONS
Sec. 20-161. - Conformity required. (a) Except as otherwise provided, no structure or land shall, after the adoption of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, be used and no structure or part thereof shall be erected, altered or moved unless in conformity with the requirements herein specified for the district in which it is located. (b) The county shall not accept any subdivision not designed, developed and recorded in accordance with the provisions of these regulations, nor shall it improve, maintain, grade or pave any street within such subdivision unless such street shall have met the specifications described herein. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-1.1, art. XIII, § 13-5(c)) Sec. 20-162. - General requirements for land development. No land shall be subdivided, sold, or transferred for development until each of the following conditions has occurred in accordance with this chapter: (1) The developer or his agent has submitted the required fees, plats and plans as described in these regulations to the zoning administrator; (2) Obtained approval of all these plats and plans, including approval of the final plat or plan by the planning and zoning board; and (3) The approved final plat is recorded with the county clerk of superior court. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-1.2) Sec. 20-163. - Unauthorized conveyances prohibited. No lot, street, alley, improvement, easement, right-of-way or other property or property right of any kind shall be conveyed, by deed or otherwise, to the county, the governing authority or other public authority without its express acceptance of such conveyance as indicated by the signature of its authorized agent on such deed or other document of conveyance. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-5(d)) Sec. 20-164. - Extension of public services restricted. The county shall not authorize the extension of water service, sewer service, or other publicly operated services of any subdivision not designed, developed and recorded in accordance with the provisions of these regulations or the extension of utility services to any parcel created in violation of these regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-5(e)) Sec. 20-165. - Area and setback requirements. Except as hereinafter provided, no building or structure shall be erected on a lot unless such building or structure, enlargement, additions or alterations conform to the area regulations and setback requirements of the zone in which it is located. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-2) Sec. 20-166. - Reduction of lot area. No lot shall be reduced, diminished and so maintained that the yards, other open space or total lot area shall be smaller than prescribed by this chapter, nor shall the density of population be increased in any manner except in conformity with the regulations herein established. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-3) Sec. 20-167. - Yards apply to only one building. No required yard or other open space around an existing building, or which is hereafter provided around any building for the purpose of complying with the provisions of this chapter, shall be considered as providing a yard or open space for any other building; nor shall any yard or other required open space on an adjoining lot be considered as providing a yard or open space on a lot whereon a building is to be erected. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-4) Sec. 20-168. - Only one main building on a lot. Every building hereafter erected or structurally altered shall be located on a lot, and in no case shall there be more than one principal building and the customary accessory buildings on one lot of land. However, in the R-A district a second principal residential building shall be allowed on a lot provided that the lot has a minimum area of 80,000 square feet and that the second principal building is located no closer than 100 linear feet from the first principal building. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-5) Sec. 20-169. - Corner visibility. No sign, construction, structure, fence, wall, hedge, bush, outdoor use or other obstruction to a clear view which extends over three feet in height shall be permitted at any corner of intersecting streets and a straight line connecting them at points 25 feet distant from the intersection of the street lines. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-6) Sec. 20-170. - Front yards on a double frontage lot. At each end of a double frontage lot there shall be a front yard of the depth required by this chapter for the zone in which each street frontage is located; provided, that one of the front yards may serve as a rear yard. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-7) Sec. 20-171. - Suitability of land for subdivision. All land physically unsuitable for subdivision shall not be improved. This includes: property affected by flooding, bad drainage, steep slopes, rock formations, or other such features which may endanger health, life or property, aggravate erosion, increase flood hazard, or necessitate excessive expenditures of public funds for supply or maintenance of services. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-8) Sec. 20-172. - Resubdividing. Parcels that are combined or uncombined as shown on the official tax appraisal map shall not be resubdivided except in conformance with all provisions of these regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-9) Sec. 20-173. - Nonresidential subdivision requirements. (a) If a proposed subdivision includes land that is zoned for commercial or industrial purposes, the layout of the subdivision with respect to the land shall make provision as the planning and zoning board may require. Site plan approval and nonresidential subdivision plat approval may proceed simultaneously at the discretion of the planning and zoning board. (b) A nonresidential subdivision shall be subject to all the requirements of these regulations, as well as such additional standards required by the planning and zoning board, and shall conform to the proposed land use and standards established in the comprehensive plan. (c) In addition to the principles and standards in these regulations, which are appropriate to the planning of all subdivisions, the applicant shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the planning and zoning board that the street, parcel, and block pattern proposed is specifically adapted to the uses anticipated and takes into account other uses in the vicinity. The following principles and standards shall be observed: (1) All proposed industrial parcels shall be suitable in area and dimension to the types of industrial development anticipated. (2) Street rights-of-way and pavement shall be adequate to accommodate the type and volume of traffic anticipated to be generated thereupon. (3) Special requirements may be imposed by the county with respect to street, curb, gutter, and sidewalk design and construction. (4) Special requirements may be imposed by the county with respect to the installation of public utilities, including water, sewer, and stormwater drainage. (5) Every effort shall be made to protect adjacent residential areas from potential nuisance from a proposed commercial or industrial subdivision, including the provision of extra depth in parcels backing up on existing or potential residential development and provisions for a permanently landscaped buffer strip as per article XV, division 4 of this chapter. (6) Streets carrying nonresidential traffic, especially truck traffic, shall not normally be extended to the boundaries of adjacent existing or potential residential areas. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, §§ 4-10.1, 4-10.2) Sec. 20-174. - Subdivision plats not subject to standards and improvements. A subdivision plat that represents four lots or less fronting on a public or private road shall not be subject to the required improvements of sections 20-390 and 20-392 and the design standards specified in article VII of this chapter, if it meets the following conditions: (1) The original tract for subdivision fronts for a distance of 150 feet on a public or private road which is identified as such on the official county road map, as adopted by the board of commissioners. (2) The size and zoning classification of each lot resulting from the subdivision meets the minimum standards set forth in this chapter. (3) Platted lots on streets and roads which have been accepted as part of established subdivisions under the minimum standards of this chapter cannot be further subdivided unless such future subdivision was made part of the original approval of the plat of such subdivision. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IV, § 4-11) Sec. 20-175. - Fees. Reasonable fees shall be paid along with the application for approval of a preliminary plat or final plat. The amount of the fees charged shall be as set forth by the board of commissioners. The schedule of fees shall be posted in the office of the zoning administrator and may be altered or amended only by the board of commissioners. Until all applicable fees have been paid in full, no action shall be taken on any application or appeal. Fees will be assessed and shall be charged to applicants to cover the cost of administration, inspection, publication of notice and similar matters for rezoning applications, appeals, conditional use permits, variance applications, subdivision plat approval, sign permits and other administrative relief. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-6) Sec. 20-176. - Exemptions to subdivision requirements. The following are excluded from the subdivision requirements of this chapter: (1) The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots comply with the standards set forth in these regulations and all other ordinances of the county. (2) The division of land into five or fewer parcels which front onto public streets and where the resultant lots conform to this chapter, provided that approval is secured from the health department in cases where septic tanks are intended to be utilized or other proper authority if central sewage disposal is intended to be utilized. Exemptions under this provision shall be verified and indicated on the plat by the zoning administrator. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XVIII, § 18-6(d)) Secs. 20-177—20-205. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PROCEDURE FOR PLAT APPROVAL
Sec. 20-206. - Applicability. The owner of any land lying within the area of jurisdiction of these regulations who wishes to subdivide such land shall seek approval by the planning and zoning board according to the procedures set forth in this article. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. V, § 5-1) Sec. 20-207. - Official submission dates. (a) For purposes of this section the term "official submission date" means the day on which the statutory period required for formal approval, conditional approval or disapproval of a preliminary or final plat begins. (b) The official submission date of a preliminary plat shall be the date of the finalization of the hearing thereon before the planning and zoning board. (c) The official submission date of a final subdivision plat shall be the date of the finalization and closure of the public meeting thereon. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. V, § 5-1) Sec. 20-208. - Pre-application consultation. (a) Prior to the review, consideration and approval of a preliminary plat by the planning and zoning board, the subdivider may schedule an initial meeting with the zoning administrator to discuss the proposed development. The developer may offer a simple sketch plan showing existing conditions within the site and in its vicinity and the proposed layout and development of the subdivision to the zoning administrator for comments if desired. (b) The purpose of the meeting is to assist the subdivider with questions he may have prior to extensive site planning necessary for the preparation of the preliminary plat and to enable the subdivider to become familiar with the regulations affecting the land to be subdivided. (c) Recommendations received from the zoning administrator concerning the proposed development or the sketch plan do not authorize the developer to begin the proposed construction or improvements. (d) No fee shall be charged for this informal consultation and no formal application shall be required. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. V, § 5-2) Sec. 20-209. - Submission of preliminary plat. Prior to making any street improvements or installing any utilities, the prospective subdivider shall submit to the planning and zoning board a preliminary plat as specified in article V of this chapter. Approval of the preliminary plat by the planning and zoning board constitutes authorization for the subdivider to develop the subdivision subject to the minimum standards for required improvements prescribed in sections 20-390 and 20-392, and the minimum design standards prescribed in article VII of this chapter. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. V, § 5-3) Sec. 20-210. - Submission of final plat. After approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider may proceed with the preparation of the final plat and other documents as may be required in connection therewith. No final plat shall be approved by the planning and zoning board until either: (1) The required improvements listed are constructed in satisfactory manner and approved by the zoning administrator and the planning and zoning board; or (2) In lieu of such prior construction, the planning and zoning board has received written notification from the county attorney that the board of commissioners has accepted an approved bond or security in the amount equal to the estimated cost of installation and completion of the required improvements, whereby improvements may be made and utilities installed without cost to the county in the event of default by the subdivider. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. V, § 5-4) Sec. 20-211. - Submission of plat of record. Upon approval of a final plat, the subdivider shall submit to the planning and zoning board for its approval a plat of record prepared in accordance with this chapter. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. V, § 5-5) Secs. 20-212—20-230. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - PRELIMINARY PLAT DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 20-231. - Application procedure. (a) The subdivider shall submit to the planning and zoning board, at least 30 days prior to the next regular meeting of the planning and zoning board, the following: (1) A letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat giving the name and address of a person to whom the notice of the hearing by the planning and zoning board on the preliminary plat shall be sent. (2) Five copies of a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision drawn to a scale not less than one inch equals 100 feet. (3) A subdivision review and inspection fee as determined by the board of commissioners. (b) The planning and zoning board shall not accept the fee until completion of the application and the requirements of this section are carried out. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-1) Sec. 20-232. - Public hearing. Upon receipt of a formal application for preliminary plat approval and all accompanying material, the planning and zoning board shall call a public hearing for the next scheduled meeting of the planning and zoning board to be held at least 30 days after the date of the application. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-12) Sec. 20-233. - Public notice. (a) Public notice of the hearing on the application for preliminary plat approval shall be given, at least 15 but not more than 45 days, prior to the scheduled public hearing. (b) The zoning administrator shall file a notice of public hearing which shall be published in the newspaper of general circulation in the county setting forth the time, place, and purpose of the hearing. Such notice shall identify the property affected. The cost of such newspaper notice shall be paid by the applicant for preliminary plat approval. (c) At least 15 days before the scheduled public hearing, the zoning administrator shall post, in a conspicuous place on the property, a sign at least two feet by three feet in size. It shall set forth the time, place and purpose of the public hearing before the planning and zoning board. (d) Additionally, notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be sent by the zoning administrator by registered or certified mail to the applicant for preliminary plat approval, not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing. (e) Acts of vandalism or natural occurrences limiting the effectiveness of notice by a sign posted on the property shall not invalidate any proceedings or action taken under this article. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-3) Sec. 20-234. - Preliminary plat approval. (a) The planning and zoning board shall approve, disapprove, or approve with modification, the preliminary plat within 60 days after the date it is presented at the public hearing. If disapproved, a notation of the planning and zoning board's action shall be made on two copies of the preliminary plat, including a statement of the reasons for disapproval. One copy will be returned to the subdivider or his agent, and one copy retained by the planning and zoning board. (b) Preliminary approval of the subdivision plat shall be noted on the plat and certified by the planning and zoning board. Also noted shall be the date on which the planning and zoning board granted preliminary approval and the date of written notification to the subdivider or subdivider's authorized agent. (c) Unless the subdivider agrees in writing to an extension of the time limitation in this section, failure of the planning and zoning board to act with 60 days from the finalization of the public hearing regarding the preliminary plat shall constitute approval thereof and a certificate of approval shall be issued by the board on demand. (d) Approval of a preliminary subdivision plat shall not constitute approval of the final subdivision plat. It only indicates approval of the layout as a guide to the preparation of the final plat. (e) Approval of the preliminary plat by the planning and zoning board constitutes authorization for the subdivider to proceed to comply with the other requirements of these regulations and the preparation of the final subdivision plat subject to the minimum standards prescribed in these regulations. However, the subdivider, subdivision owner, or agent of the subdivider or owner shall not transfer, sell, agree to sell, or negotiate to sell any part of the subdivision by reference or exhibition until after the planning and zoning board has approved the final plat and the applicant has filed the plat of record with the clerk of the county superior court. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-4) Sec. 20-235. - Standards for approval of preliminary plats. (a) No preliminary plat of a proposed subdivision shall be approved by the planning and zoning board unless the applicant proves by clear and convincing evidence that: (1) Definite provision has been made for a water supply that is sufficient in terms of quantity, dependability, and quality to provide an appropriate supply of water for the type of subdivision proposed; (2) If a public sewage system is proposed, adequate provision has been made for such a system and, if other methods of sewage disposal are proposed, that such systems will comply with federal, state, and local laws and regulations; (3) All proposed streets on the preliminary plat are in conformity with adopted design standards, and existing and proposed public street improvements; (4) All areas of the proposed subdivision which may involve soil or topographical conditions presenting hazards or requiring special precautions have been identified by the subdivider and that the proposed uses of these areas are compatible with such conditions. (b) The planning and zoning board is authorized to disapprove the preliminary plat even though the land proposed for subdivision is zoned for the use to which the proposed subdivision will be put and the proposed use is consistent with the comprehensive plan. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-5) Sec. 20-236. - Public improvements. The planning and zoning board may require that all public improvements be installed and dedicated prior to the signing of the final subdivision plat. The planning and zoning board shall require the applicant to indicate on the plat all roads and public utility improvements which shall be required to be established or extended, and any other special requirements deemed necessary by the planning and zoning board in order to conform the subdivision plat to the county comprehensive plan. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-6) Sec. 20-237. - Effective period of preliminary plat approval. The approval of a preliminary plat shall be effective for a period of one year from the date that the preliminary plat is approved by the planning and zoning board, at the end of which time the applicant must have submitted a final subdivision plat for approval. If a subdivision plat is not submitted for final approval within the one-year period, the preliminary approval shall be null and void, and the applicant shall be required to submit a new plat for preliminary plat review subject to the then-existing zoning restrictions and subdivision regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-7) Secs. 20-238—20-267. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PLAT REQUIREMENTS
Sec. 20-268. - General conditions. The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet and meet the minimum standards of design set forth in these regulations and shall include the following information: (1) Full name, location and acreage of proposed subdivision. (2) Name, address, and telephone number of owner of record and subdivider, and architect, surveyor, engineer or designer. (3) All names and addresses of adjoining subdivisions or all deed record owners of the land adjacent to the site. (4) Date, scale, and north arrow on map. (5) Total number of lots and average lot size. (6) Location or vicinity map at a scale of not less than one inch equals one mile tying the subdivision into the present road system and relating the subdivision to its surrounding area. (7) A written legal description (metes and bounds with all bearing and distances) of the acreage to be subdivided. (8) Proper identification of the boundaries of the tract to be subdivided with all bearings and distances indicated. The boundary survey shall be to such a degree of accuracy that the error of closure is 1:7,500 or greater. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-8.1) Sec. 20-269. - Existing conditions. The preliminary plat shall include the following existing conditions: (1) Topographic map on a scale of one inch representing 100 feet or less and contour intervals of five feet or less, showing major watercourses, marshes, rock outcrops, wooded areas, and other outstanding features. (2) Zoning district classification of land to be subdivided and adjoining land (if applicable). (3) In case of resubdivision, a copy of the existing plat with proposed resubdivision superimposed thereon. (4) Location of natural features such as streams, lakes, swamps, and land subject to flood based on a 100-year flood frequency on the property to be subdivided. (5) Location of existing adjoining property lines and existing buildings on the property to be subdivided. (6) Location and right-of-way of streets, roads, railroads and utility lines either on or adjacent to the property to be subdivided, specifying whether utility lines are in easements or right-of-way and showing the location of poles or towers. (7) Size and location of existing sewers, water mains, drains, culverts or other underground facilities within the street or within the right-of-way of streets or roads adjoining the tract. Grades and invert elevations of sewers shall be shown. (8) The acreage of each drainage area affecting the proposed subdivision. (9) All elevations shall refer to mean sea level datum where public water or public sewers are to be installed. (10) Location of city limit lines and county lines (if applicable). (11) Location of any wetlands situated on the property to be subdivided. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-8.2) Sec. 20-270. - Proposed conditions. The preliminary plat shall include the following proposed conditions: (1) Layout of streets, roads, alleys, public crosswalks, with widths, road names, or designations, grades and cross sections. (2) Profile of proposed streets showing natural and finished grades with percent of grade slope. (3) Detailed layout of all lots, including building setback lines, scaled dimensions on lots, utility easements with width and use. (4) Construction drawings of sanitary sewers (if applicable) with grade, pipe size, location of manholes, and points of discharge and percolation tests, soil borings and wells as specified by the health department. (5) Construction drawings of storm sewer system with grade, pipe size, and location of outlet. Storm sewers shall be sized to accommodate runoff from a ten-year frequency rainfall. (6) Plans of all drainage provisions, retaining walls, curbing, planting, anti-erosion devices or other protective devices to be constructed in connection with, or as a part of the proposed work, together with a map showing the drainage area of land tributary to the site and estimated runoff of the area served by any drains. (7) Construction drawings of water supply system with pipe size and location of hydrants and valves. (8) Designation of all land (if any) to be reserved or dedicated for public use. (9) Designation of proposed use of all lots to be used for other than single-family residential (if any). (10) Proposed major contour changes to areas where substantial cut or fill is to be done. (11) A timing schedule indicating the anticipated starting and completion dates of the development sequence and the time of exposure of each area prior to the completion of effective erosion and sediment control measures. (12) Total number of lots, total acreage, total length and width of new streets. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-8.3) Sec. 20-271. - Certificate of preliminary approval. A certificate of approval of the preliminary plat by the planning and zoning board shall be inscribed on the plat as follows: Pursuant to county land use and development regulations, all the requirements for approval have been fulfilled. This preliminary plat was given preliminary approval by the county planning and zoning board on ___________, 20___. This preliminary approval does not constitute approval of a final plat. This certificate of approval shall expire and be null and void on ___________, 20___.
(Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VI, § 6-9) Secs. 20-272—20-290. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - FINAL PLAT
Sec. 20-291. - Application procedure. The final subdivision plat shall be prepared in accordance with the standards set forth in this article and O.C.G.A. title 15, ch. 6, art. 2 (O.C.G.A. § 15-6-50 et seq.). (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-1) Sec. 20-292. - Time limit for submitting application. After the preliminary plat of a proposed land subdivision has been given approval by the planning and zoning board, the subdivider may, within one year from the date of such approval, submit to the planning and zoning board an original and two duplicate copies of the final subdivision plat application prepared in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, together with two Mylar sepias. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-1.1(a)) Sec. 20-293. - Content of application. The zoning administrator shall check the final plat application for conformance with the approved preliminary plat and with the provisions of this chapter. Each plat shall contain, in such language as prescribed by the planning and zoning board, a certificate by the surveyor as to survey and platting requirements; a certificate by the engineer as to engineering requirements; a certificate as to floor elevation as related to the sanitary sewer system; a certification of acceptance by the planning and zoning board; and if approved, a certificate of final plat approval by the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-1.1(b)) Sec. 20-294. - Certificate of ownership. The application for final plat approval shall be accompanied by a certificate by the owner as to ownership and all formal irrevocable offers of dedication to the public of streets, easements, utilities, parks, and open spaces. For purposes hereof, authentication shall be in the certificate of ownership and dedication form as provided in section 20-297. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-1.1(c)) Sec. 20-295. - Warranty deed and other required documentation. The applicant shall deliver a full covenant and warranty deed to all dedicated lands and improvements in proper form for recording, together with any requirement deemed necessary by the county attorney before he shall sign the final subdivision plat. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-1.1(d)) Sec. 20-296. - Final plat contents. Plats shall be produced on polyester film not larger than 17 inches by 24 inches and signed by the surveyor. Plats shall be drawn to a scale of one inch equals not more than 100 feet and shall show the following information, where applicable: (1) Full name, location and acreage of proposed subdivision; (2) Name, address, and telephone number of the owner of record and the subdivider, and as applicable, the architect, surveyor, engineer or designer; (3) All names and addresses of adjoining subdivisions or all deed record owners of the land adjacent to the site; (4) Date, scale, and north arrow on map; (5) Total number of lots and average lot size; (6) The vicinity map showing exact location of the subdivision in relation to the surrounding area and showing streets or roads at a scale of one inch equals 1,000 feet; (7) Exact boundary lines of the subdivision tract, names and locations of adjoining subdivisions and streets, the location and ownership of adjoining property; (8) Layout of streets showing street names, rights-of-way, pavement widths, street classifications, and street centerlines showing angles of deflection, angles of intersection, radii, and lengths of tangents; (9) Lot lines with dimensions and bearings, minimum front building setback lines, lots numbered in numerical order, blocks lettered alphabetically, and the area of each lot; (10) Locations, dimensions and purposes of any easements, recreational areas, land to be dedicated for public use, land to be used for purposes other than residential, and land for future development. All dimensions to be to the nearest one-hundredth of a foot and all bearings and angles to the nearest minute; (11) Locations, material and descriptions of monuments and markers; (12) Sufficient data to determine readily and reproduce on the ground the location, bearing and length of every street, lot line, boundary line, front building setback line and block line, whether curved or straight; (13) A complete current mailing address of the surveyor, engineer or other preparer of said plat; (14) Floodplain data; and (15) Such other information as may be required by the planning and zoning board or county health department. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-5(a)—(p)) Sec. 20-297. - Certificates. The following signed certificates shall appear on the final plat which is submitted to the planning and zoning board by the subdivider: (1) Certificate of approval for recording. (To be placed on an original of the approved final plat by the planning and zoning board and returned to the subdivider for recording.) The subdivision plat known as ___________ has been found to comply with the county land use and development regulations and was approved by the planning and zoning board on the ___ day of ___________, 20___, for the recording in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court of Jefferson County, Georgia.
(2) Certificate of accuracy. I hereby certify that this plat is a true, correct and accurate survey as required by the county land use and development regulations and was prepared from an actual survey of the property made under my supervision, and that monuments shown have been located and placed to the specifications set forth in said regulations.
(3) Certificate of ownership and dedication, individuals. It is hereby certified that I am (we are) the owners of the property shown and described hereon and that I (we) hereby irrevocably dedicate all streets, alleys, walks, parks and other sites to public or private use as noted. It is further certified that the streets, drainage system, sewer system and water system in ___________ Subdivision as shown on the plat dated ________ prepared by ___________ have (has) been installed in accordance with the preliminary plat (construction drawings) approved (date) ________. It is understood this is not an assumption of maintenance by the governing authority. This dedication is for the public's right of ingress and egress only.
(Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-5(q)) Sec. 20-298. - Final plat determination. (a) The planning and zoning board shall schedule the final subdivision plat determination for its next available regular meeting agenda. Public notice of final plat determination shall be given at least 15, but not more than 45 days prior to the next available regular meeting. The zoning administrator shall file a written notice which shall be published in the newspaper of general circulation in the county setting forth the time, place, and purpose of the meeting. Such notice shall identify the property affected. The cost of such newspaper notice shall be paid by the applicant for final plat approval. (b) At the meeting, the planning and zoning board shall approve, disapprove, or approve with modification, the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original and duplicate plats and one Mylar sepia of the final plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the final plat is disapproved. (c) If action on the final plat is not taken by the planning and zoning board within 60 days of the date of submittal, the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-2) Sec. 20-299. - Approval required for recordation. No plat of a subdivision within the county shall be filed or recorded by the clerk of the county superior court until the final plat shall have been prepared, submitted to, approved and recorded according to these regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-5(b)) Sec. 20-300. - Recording. (a) After approval of the final subdivision plat by the planning and zoning board, the plat shall be filed for record in the office of the clerk of the county superior court. (b) The clerk of the superior court shall not accept for record or file any plat which has not been prepared in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and which has not been stamped approved by the planning and zoning board. For purposes hereof, authentication shall be in the certificate of approval for recording form as provided in section 20-297. (c) One blueprint, shall be filed with the clerk of superior court who shall enter thereon the filing date. One Mylar copy shall be delivered to the planning and zoning board as required. One copy of all deeds and plats with recording information shall be delivered to the tax assessor's office. (d) Any person requesting a copy of the recorded plat shall include an extra blueprint copy at the time of filing for record. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-3) Sec. 20-301. - Plat approval not acceptance of dedication offers. The approval of a plat does not constitute acceptance by the county of the offer of dedication of any streets, sidewalks, parks or other public facilities shown on a plat. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-4) Secs. 20-302—20-320. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - DESIGN STANDARDS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 20-321. - Applicability. The design standards contained in this article shall apply to all new development and they shall conform to the minimum requirements of the property's zoning designation as required in this chapter. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-1) Sec. 20-322. - Name of subdivisions. The name of each subdivision must have the approval of the planning and zoning board. The name shall not duplicate nor closely approximate the name of an existing subdivision. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-5) Sec. 20-323. - Fire hydrants. In accordance with this chapter, the adequate provision of fire hydrants necessitates that: (1) Every development subdivided or unsubdivided that is served by a public water system shall include a system of fire hydrants sufficient to provide adequate fire protection for the buildings located or intended to be located within such development. (2) Water lines that serve hydrants shall be at least six-inch lines, and, unless no other practicable alternative is available, no such line shall be dead-end lines. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-5(r)) Sec. 20-324. - Topsoil. Wherever grading or filling occurs on lots within the subdivision, the subdivider shall first stockpile the topsoil from the affected areas immediately after grading and filling and shall redistribute to areas of disturbed soil sufficient topsoil to support growth of lawn grass, and other vegetation and shall immediately seed such areas with appropriate vegetative cover to prevent erosion, silting of streams, and other damages. Due regard shall be shown for such desirable trees as are already on the site, and grading and filling should be planned to preserve as many as possible. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-5(t)) Sec. 20-325. - Soil suitability. The planning and zoning board shall not approve a subdivision where the soil conditions have been determined not suitable for development by the county health department pursuant to local, state, and federal laws, regulations and standards. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-6) Sec. 20-326. - Blocks. (a) Length. Blocks shall be neither less than 400 feet nor more than 1,200 feet in length, except as the planning and zoning board considers necessary to secure efficient use of land or desired features of street pattern. In blocks greater than 800 feet in length, the planning and zoning board may require at locations it deems necessary one or more public crosswalks of not less than ten feet in width to extend entirely across the block, or pedestrian easements in lieu thereof. (b) Width. Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two rows of lots, except where reverse frontage on major streets is provided or when prevented by topographic conditions or size of property or location next to an arterial road, in which case the planning and zoning board may approve a single row of lots. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-3) Sec. 20-327. - Utility easements. Except where alleys or rear service drives are permitted for the purpose, easements along rear or side lot lines shall be at least 15 feet wide and shall be required for the extension of existing or planned utilities. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-4(a)) Secs. 20-328—20-357. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - EASEMENTS
Sec. 20-358. - Drainage easements. In cases in which a subdivision is traversed by a stream or drainage channel, there shall be provided a stormwater easement of such width along each side of the stream as the planning and zoning board deems necessary for the purpose of widening, deepening, protecting, relocating, or otherwise improving such drainage element. Additional requirements include: (1) A five-foot easement along all side property lines. (2) A ten-foot easement along all rear property lines. (3) All storm drainage pipes shall be located within a ten-foot easement. (4) All stormwater discharge into natural drainage areas shall be as straight as possible. (5) All storm drainage pipes shall be at least 18 inches in diameter and 18 inches below the surface and shall have a slope of at least one percent. (6) Catchbasins shall be located at all low points of streets and shall be located so as to service no more than four acres. (7) High-water elevation contour based on a 25-year storm at the entrance of each head wall. (8) All drainage easements, natural ditches, and drainage areas shall be grassed or rip-rapped as necessary to control erosion. (9) All subdivisions plans shall include a method of control so as to prevent the silting or erosion of natural drainage areas, natural drains and streams, and adjoining property; such plans shall also provide for control of the rate of discharge of excess water. (10) In addition to the requirements of these regulations, all property located in a floodprone area shall be developed in accordance with the minimum state and federal standards governing floodprone areas. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-4(b)) Secs. 20-359—20-389. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - STREETS
Sec. 20-390. - Dedications. After the adoption of a major street plan as provided by law, the county or other public authority shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave or light any street or authorize the laying of water mains, sewers, connections or other facilities or utilities in any street within the territorial jurisdiction of the county unless such street has been accepted or opened as, or shall otherwise have received the legal status of, a public street prior to the attachment of the county's jurisdiction, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat duly approved by the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 8-3) Sec. 20-391. - Subdivision entrances. (a) At the preliminary plat stage, the planning and zoning board may limit the number of entrances, driveways, or curb cuts. (b) At the preliminary and final plat stages, the planning and zoning board shall be consistent with all state, federal, and local laws and applicable ordinances, including the state department of transportation rules and all amendments or revisions in effect as of the date of the preliminary plat approval. (c) At the preliminary plat stage, the planning and zoning board may consider safety as well as require available alternatives for reducing the number of entrances, driveways or curb cuts. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-5(u)) Sec. 20-392. - Access. The planning and zoning board shall not approve a subdivision in a location where the existing roads providing primary access are inadequate to serve the additional traffic generated by the development. If the ditches on existing county streets are to be used for drainage from the subdivision, the developer will re-grade said ditches and provide an all-weather drainage outlet. All re-grading and drainage outlets shall be approved by the board of commissioners or its authorized representatives. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 8-4) Sec. 20-393. - Street name signs. Street name signs shall be installed at all intersections within a subdivision. The location and design shall be approved by the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. VII, § 7-5(s)) Sec. 20-394. - Street requirements generally. In order to provide for streets of suitable location, width and improvements to accommodate prospective traffic and afford satisfactory access to fire, police and sanitation department personnel as well as road maintenance equipment, and to coordinate streets so as to compose a convenient system and avoid hardships to adjoining property, the design standards in this article for streets are hereby required and shall be planned for and provided by the subdivider, prior to final plat approval. Streets shall conform to current county road construction and maintenance specifications. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2) Sec. 20-395. - Street classification. Streets and roads are hereby classified according to the function which they are to serve, the type, speed, and volume of traffic they will carry, and the required standards of design. The classifications of streets and roads shall be arterial roads, collector streets, and local streets; and are displayed on the major road plan adopted by the planning and zoning board. The designation in the major road plan of arterials and collectors shall not prevent other streets proposed in or adjoining subdivisions from being similarly classified. Street classifications and subclassifications are as follows: (1) Arterial roads or streets. (2) Collector streets. (3) Local streets. a. Residential: 1. Small lot subdivisions (lots less than 50,000 square feet). 2. Large lot subdivisions (lots larger than 50,000 square feet with a minimum frontage of 125 lineal feet). 3. Rural subdivisions (lots larger than 2.5 acres). 4. Large lot rural subdivisions (lots larger than 5.0 acres). b. Industrial. c. Commercial. d. Service drive. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.1) Sec. 20-396. - Relation to present, proposed and future street system. (a) The location and width of all streets and roads shall conform to the official major road plan as adopted by the planning and zoning board. (b) Existing streets which terminate at or adjoin a subdivision boundary shall be deemed a part of the subdivision. The proposed street system within a subdivision shall have the right-of-way of existing streets extended no less than the required minimum width. Subdivisions that adjoin only one side of existing streets shall dedicate one-half of the additional right-of-way needed to meet minimum width requirements. If any part of the subdivision includes both sides of an existing street all the required additional right-of-way shall be dedicated. (c) The proposed street layout shall be coordinated with the street system of the surrounding area. Where possible, existing major streets shall be extended. (d) Where, in the opinion of the planning and zoning board it is necessary to provide for street access to adjoining property, proposed streets shall be extended by dedication of right-of-way to the boundary of such property. (e) When an arterial road adjoins or is included in a subdivision, lots therein which abut the arterial road shall be provided with another means of access, e.g. platting a single tier of lots which back to the arterial road and front on a minor street, platting a service drive, platting a looped land service street and culs-de-sac, platting a rear service drive for access, or other methods approved by the planning and zoning board. Subdivision streets which intersect an arterial road shall do so at intervals not less 1,200 feet for limited access arterial roads and 400 feet for other arterial roads. (f) When land is subdivided into parcels larger than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged so as to allow for the opening of streets in the future. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.2) Sec. 20-397. - Street names. Proposed streets which are obviously in alignment with other existing and named streets shall bear the assigned name of the existing streets. In no case shall the name of the proposed streets duplicate or be phonetically similar to existing street names, regardless of the use of suffix, street, avenue, boulevard, drive, place, court, etc. It shall be unlawful for any person in laying out any new street or road to name such street or road on any plat by marking, or in any deed or instrument, without first getting approval of the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.3) Sec. 20-398. - Street jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets by less than the minimum stopping distance specified in this division shall be prohibited. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.4) Sec. 20-399. - Right angle intersections. Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as practicable. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.5) Sec. 20-400. - Culs-de-sac. A cul-de-sac is a minor street and is not to extend more than 700 feet in length. Such street shall be provided with a turnaround having a roadway diameter of at least 80 feet and a right-of-way diameter of at least 100 feet. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.6) Sec. 20-401. - Alleys. Service alleys or drives may be required in multiple dwelling, commercial, and industrial developments and shall have a minimum surface treatment width of 15 feet, but shall not be provided in one- and two-family residential developments unless the subdivider provides evidence satisfactory to the planning and zoning board of the need for alleys. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.7) Sec. 20-402. - Entrances to streets. All driveway entrances and other openings onto streets within the county's jurisdiction shall be constructed so that: (1) Interference with the free and convenient flow of traffic in abutting or surrounding streets is minimized; (2) No point of ingress/egress shall be allowed within 35 feet of the right-of-way line of any street intersection; (3) An ingress/egress driveway shall be located not closer than 30 feet to another such driveway on the same street. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.8) Sec. 20-403. - Access to arterial roads. When a subdivision is proposed with frontage along an existing arterial road, or state numbered highway, every attempt must be made to provide an access road or frontage road for direct access to the proposed lots. The planning and zoning board shall evaluate this requirement in an attempt to reduce the number and frequency of curb cuts along arterial roads and state numbered highways. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.9) Sec. 20-404. - Street right-of-way widths. Street rights-of-way are designed and developed to serve several functions: to carry motor vehicle traffic, and in some cases, allow on-street parking; to provide a safe and convenient passageway for pedestrian traffic; and to serve as an important link in the county's drainage system. In order to fulfill these objectives, minimum street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: (1) Curb-and-gutter type of construction.
(2) Shoulder lane type of construction.
(Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.10) Sec. 20-405. - Vertical alignment of streets; grades. (a) Grades on arterial, collector and industrial streets shall not exceed seven percent; grades on commercial streets shall not exceed ten percent; grades on residential streets shall not exceed 13 percent; all curbed and paved raised edge streets shall have a minimum grade of one percent. (b) All changes in grade shall be connected by a vertical curve so constructed as to afford a minimum sight distance, said sight distance being measured from the driver's eyes, which are assumed to be 3¾ feet above the pavement surface, to an object six inches high on the pavement. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.11) Sec. 20-406. - Minimum sight distance. The minimum sight distance shall be the minimum stopping sight distance for the rated speed of the street as follows:
(Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.11) Sec. 20-407. - Horizontal alignment of streets. (a) Where a deflection angle of more than ten degrees in the alignment of a street occurs, the radius of curvature of the centerline of said street shall be not less than as follows:
(b) A tangent of at least 100 feet in length shall be introduced between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets. (c) Right-of-way lines at street intersections shall have a radius of curvature of not less than 20 feet. Wherever necessary to permit the construction of a curb having a desirable radius without curtailing the sidewalk at a street corner to less than normal width, the street right-of-way line at such street corner shall be rounded or otherwise set back sufficiently to permit such construction. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. IX, § 9-2.12) Secs. 20-408—20-427. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - IMPROVEMENT GUARANTEES
Sec. 20-428. - Purpose. Improvement guarantees shall be provided to ensure the proper installation and maintenance of required streets, utility and other improvements. The nature and duration of the guarantee shall be structured to achieve this goal without adding unnecessary costs to the developer of a proposed subdivision. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. X, § 10-1) Sec. 20-429. - Application. (a) Before recording the final plat, or as a condition of final site plan approval, the planning and zoning board may require and shall accept in accordance with the requirements of this chapter the following guarantees: (1) The furnishing of a performance guarantee in an amount not to exceed 120 percent of the cost of installation of improvements; (2) The provision for a maintenance guarantee for a period not to exceed two years after final acceptance of the improvement, in an amount not to exceed 15 percent of the cost of the improvement. In the event that other governmental agencies or public utilities automatically will own the utilities to be installed, or the improvements are covered by a performance guarantee or maintenance guarantee to another governmental agency, no performance guarantee or maintenance guarantee shall be required by the planning and zoning board for such utilities or improvements. (b) The time allowed for installation of the improvements for which the performance guarantee has been provided may be extended by the planning and zoning board by resolution. (c) Upon substantial completion of all required improvements, the developer may notify the planning and zoning board in writing of the completion or substantial completion of improvement and it shall send a copy to the building inspector. The building inspector shall inspect all improvements of which such notice has been given and shall file a detailed report, in writing with the planning and zoning board indicating either approval, partial approval or rejection of such improvements with a statement of reasons for any rejection. The cost of the improvements as approved or rejected shall be set forth. (d) The planning and zoning board shall either approve, partially approve, or reject the improvements on the basis of the report of the building inspector and it shall notify the developer in writing of the contents of the report and the action not later than 30 days after receipt of the notice from the developer of the completion of the improvements. Failure of the planning and zoning board to provide notification within 30 days after receipt of the notice from the developer of the completion of the improvements shall be held to constitute approval of the improvement and the obligor as well as the surety, if any, shall be released from all liability pursuant to such performance guarantee for such improvements. (e) Where partial approval is granted, the developer shall be released from all liability except for that portion of improvements not yet approved. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. X, § 10-2) Sec. 20-430. - Performance and maintenance mechanisms. The performance and maintenance guarantees shall be provided by a variety of means including, but not limited to the following: (1) Security bond. The applicant may obtain a security bond from a surety bonding company authorized to do business in this state. (2) Letter of credit. The applicant may provide an irrevocable letter of credit from a bank. (3) Escrow account. The applicant shall deposit cash or other instruments readily convertible into cash at face value, either with the county, or in escrow with a bank. (4) Subdivision improvement agreement. An applicant may provide as a guarantee a Subdivision Improvement Agreement between the lender, applicant and the county. (5) Cash bond. A cash bond in the amount of $1,000.00 will be required of all timber harvesting operators using county-maintained roads. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. X, § 10-3) Secs. 20-431—20-458. - Reserved. ARTICLE IX. - CONSTRUCTION SCHEDULE
Sec. 20-459. - Prior approval. No construction activity of any kind, including grading, installation of improvements, and building, shall begin on any land subject to these regulations without prior approval of the preliminary plat by the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XI, § 11-1) Sec. 20-460. - Grading. The grading operations may begin following approval of the preliminary plat. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XI, § 11-2) Sec. 20-461. - Utilities. Utility installation shall not occur until the zoning administrator has approved the rough grade of the street and shoulder preparation. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XI, § 11-3) Sec. 20-462. - Inspections. Periodic inspection during the installation of the physical improvements in a subdivision shall be made by the zoning administrator to ensure conformity with the approved plans and specifications. The subdivider shall notify the zoning administrator when each phase of the installation is completed and ready for inspection. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XI, § 11-4) Sec. 20-463. - Sale and transfer. No lot or parcel of land shall be sold or transferred or a building permit issued until the final plat, of which said lot or parcel is a part, shall have been approved and recorded as provided for in these regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XI, § 11-5) Sec. 20-464. - Building permits. The zoning administrator or building inspector shall not issue any permit for the erection of any building or structure to be located in any subdivision, of which a plat is required to be recorded pursuant to the provisions of these regulations, until such plat shall have been admitted to record as provided for in these regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XI, § 11-6) Sec. 20-465. - Occupancy. No dwelling within the county may be occupied for dwelling purposes until all required utility installations, including water supply and sanitary sewer systems, have been completed to the satisfaction of the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XI, § 11-7) Secs. 20-466—20-483. - Reserved. ARTICLE X. - CONDITIONAL USES
Sec. 20-484. - Generally. Some zoning districts permit certain uses only upon approval of the planning and zoning board. These uses are identified in this chapter as conditional uses and such uses may be allowed under special conditions. The granting of a conditional use does not constitute a permanent change in zoning or use. The conditional use may be forfeited if it does not meet the criteria provided in this article. Generally, a conditional use shall be compatible with the applicable zoning district under special conditions. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-2) Sec. 20-485. - Approval. Conditional uses shall be permitted subject to an approval by the planning and zoning board according to procedures established in this chapter. The required review shall determine whether the uses conform to the standards set forth in this article. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-2(a)) Sec. 20-486. - Conditional use standards. The conditional use shall be approved if it meets all the following factors: (1) A rezoning to a more intensive zoning district, which contains that use as a use by right, would not be appropriate for the property. (2) The location and character of the conditional use shall be compatible with the community development pattern and consistent with the needs of the neighborhood. (3) The conditional use will not be injurious to the use and enjoyment of the natural environment or of other property in the immediate vicinity, or diminish and impair property values within the surrounding neighborhood. (4) The conditional use will not increase state or local expenditures in relation to the cost of servicing or maintaining neighborhood properties. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-2(b)) Sec. 20-487. - Additional conditions and development standards. (a) The planning and zoning board may impose any additional conditions and development standards, along with the grant of the conditional use, as may be necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of surrounding landowners, neighborhoods and workers. The planning and zoning board may require as part of its approval, the following conditions: (1) Planted or screen buffers to reduce adverse or potentially adverse effects on adjoining properties. (2) Limitation of street accessways, parking areas, and loading docks. (3) The rearrangement of structures on the development site. (4) Increases in maximum building height. (5) Increases in the district requirements for lot size and building line setbacks, but not a reduction of these requirements. (6) Limitations on the hours of business operation when it can be shown that proposed operational times would cause an adverse effect on adjoining existing uses. (7) Specified distances from existing residential, public, or institutional developments. (b) In no case, however, shall the planning and zoning board exempt any conditional use from meeting the minimum lot and structure requirements of the zoning district in which the proposed use is to be located. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-2(c)) Secs. 20-488—20-512. - Reserved. ARTICLE XI. - VARIANCES
Sec. 20-513. - Generally. (a) The planning and zoning board shall hear and decide applications for variances from the requirements of this chapter, but only in individual cases of practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship. These include: (1) Exceptional narrowness, shallowness or shape of a specific piece of property, which at the time of adoption of this chapter, was a lot or plat of record; or (2) Where, by reason of exceptional topographic conditions or other extraordinary or exceptional conditions of a piece of property, the strict application of the development requirements of this chapter would result in practical difficulties to, or undue hardship upon the owner of such property. (b) However, the planning and zoning board shall not be authorized to grant a density variance or a use variance to permit a use in a district in which the use is prohibited. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3) Sec. 20-514. - Variance standards. No variance shall be granted unless the planning and zoning board finds that all of the following conditions exist: (1) The special circumstances or conditions applying to the building or land in question are peculiar to the land involved and do not apply generally to other land or buildings in the vicinity; (2) The strict application of the provisions of this chapter to this particular piece of property would create an unnecessary hardship by depriving the applicant of any reasonable use of his land. Mere loss in value shall not justify a variance from this chapter. There must be a deprivation of the beneficial use of land; (3) The condition from which relief of a variance is sought did not result from action by the applicant; (4) Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of this chapter; provided, however, that no variance may be granted for a use of land or building or structure that is prohibited in a given district by this chapter. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3) Sec. 20-515. - Burden of proof. In reviewing an application for a variance, the burden of showing that the variance should be granted shall be upon the person applying therefor. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3) Sec. 20-516. - Conditional variance. The planning and zoning board when granting a variance, may establish reasonable conditions concerning the use of said property and may establish a time period for said variance so that the purpose of this chapter will be served and to provide adequately for the maintenance of the integrity and character of the zone in which such permit is granted. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3.1) Sec. 20-517. - Guarantees. When necessary, the planning and zoning board may require guarantees, in such form as it deems proper, to insure that conditions designated in connection therewith are being or will be complied with. Where any condition under which a request has been granted appears to have been violated, the planning and zoning board may hold a public hearing thereon to determine whether or not the permit granted shall be terminated. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3.2) Sec. 20-518. - Subdivision improvements and minimum design standards variances. The planning and zoning board may grant variances from the required improvements and minimum standards of design contained in this chapter, provided the subdivider makes a specific request and shows to the satisfaction of the planning and zoning board that topographical or other conditions peculiar and particular to the site are such that strict adherence to the requirements would cause him unnecessary hardship and would not carry out the intent of these regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3.3) Sec. 20-519. - Time for making determination. The planning and zoning board shall consider and decide whether to grant approval or disapproval of a variance request within 45 days after the public hearing, as specified in this chapter, in accordance with the standards set forth above. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3.4) Sec. 20-520. - Records. The grant of approval or disapproval of a variance request by the planning and zoning board shall be stated in the minutes with the reasons for departure from the strict application of this article and the conditions under which the variance was granted. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3.5) Sec. 20-521. - Termination of variance. Any variance granted shall terminate automatically when the use ceases to be in full compliance with any conditions imposed by the planning and zoning board, when the use has been abandoned or when the building permit shall have expired. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XII, § 12-3.5) Secs. 20-522—20-550. - Reserved. ARTICLE XII. - PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES
Sec. 20-551. - Building permits required. (a) It shall be unlawful to commence the excavation for or the construction of any building or structure including accessory structures, or to commence the moving, alteration or repair of any structure including accessory structures, until the zoning administrator has issued for such work a building permit containing a statement that the plans, specifications and intended use of such structure in all respects conform with the provisions of this chapter. (b) No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure located on a lot or plat subdivided or sold in violation of the provisions of these regulations. (c) No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the county unless the street giving access to such lot upon which said building is proposed to be placed shall be accepted and opened as, or shall otherwise receive the legal status of, a public street prior to that time, or unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a plat approved by the planning and zoning board. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-2) Sec. 20-552. - Application for building permit. (a) Application for a building permit shall be made in writing to the zoning administrator on forms provided for that purpose. It shall be unlawful for the zoning administrator to approve the plans or issue a building permit for any excavation or construction until he has inspected such plans in detail and found them to be in conformity with this chapter. To this end, the zoning administrator may require that every application for a building permit for excavation, construction, moving or alteration shall be accompanied by a plan or plat drawn to scale and showing the following in sufficient detail to enable the zoning administrator to ascertain whether the proposed excavation, construction, moving or alteration is in conformance with this chapter. The plat shall include: (1) The actual shape, location and dimensions of the lot to be built upon. (2) The shape, height, use and location on the lot, building or structures to be erected or altered. (3) The sizes, locations and use of all existing buildings or structures on the lot. (4) The number of dwelling units the building, if residential, is designed to accommodate. (5) The setback lines of building and unloading spaces. (6) The layout of off-street parking and unloading spaces. (7) Signature of the county health officer approving the proposed location of the septic tank and field lines where public sewerage is not available. (8) Such other information concerning the lot or adjoining lots as may be essential in determining whether the provisions of this chapter are being observed. (b) If the proposed excavation, construction, moving or alteration as set forth in the application for a building permit is in conformity with the provisions of this chapter, the zoning administrator shall issue a building permit for such excavation, construction, moving or alteration. (c) If the application for a building permit is not approved, the zoning administrator shall state in writing on the application the cause for such disapproval. Issuance of a permit shall, in no case, be construed as waiving any provision of this chapter, and building permits shall be void after six months from date of issue unless substantial progress on the project has been made by that time. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-3) Sec. 20-553. - Certificates of occupancy. (a) No land or building or other structure or part thereof hereafter erected, moved or altered in its use shall be occupied or used until the building inspector has issued a certificate of occupancy. (b) A certificate of occupancy shall be issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. If the certificate of occupancy is not granted upon request, the zoning administrator shall state in writing the reasons why the certificate was not granted. (c) The county shall not issue certificates of occupancy to any owner of a parcel created in violation of these regulations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIII, § 13-4) Secs. 20-554—20-584. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIII. - NONCONFORMING STRUCTURES OR USES
Sec. 20-585. - Purpose. The purpose of this article is to provide for the continuation and within a suitable period of time, elimination of existing uses of property that do not conform to the requirements of this chapter upon its adoption or subsequent amendment. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIV, § 14-1) Sec. 20-586. - Continuance of nonconforming uses. (a) The lawful use of any building or structure or land existing at the time of the enactment or subsequent amendment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived may be continued even though such use does not conform with provisions of this chapter, except that the nonconforming structure or use shall not be: (1) Changed to another nonconforming use; (2) Re-established after discontinuance for one year; (3) Extended or enlarged beyond its size at the time the structure or use become nonconforming. This restriction includes but is not limited to the size of the building, the number of employees, operation during other hours of the day or night, or the use of additional land and additional or more powerful equipment; or (4) Rebuilt, altered, repaired or replaced after incurring damages exceeding 75 percent or more of its replacement cost at the time or condition except in conformity with this chapter. A nonconforming mobile home may not be replaced after it is removed from the property. (b) Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prevent the strengthening or restoring to safe condition of any building or part thereof declared to be unsafe by any official charged with protecting the public safety, upon order of such official. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIV, § 14-2) Sec. 20-587. - Nonconforming signs. Certain nonconforming signs shall be brought into compliance according to the following schedules: (1) In all zoning districts, any nonconforming sign cannot be added to or expanded. (2) In all zoning districts, any nonconforming sign which is damaged to the extent of 75 percent or more of its value must be brought into compliance prior to repair or rehabilitation. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIV, § 14-3) Sec. 20-588. - Temporary use of modular offices, manufactured homes and travel trailers. (a) The zoning administrator shall have the authority to issue a temporary use permit allowing a modular office, manufactured home or travel trailer to be placed on an individual lot for a nonresidential use where the applicant for such permit shows that it is necessary to use such modular office, manufactured home or travel trailer as an office or work area for the preparation and completion of a construction project. (b) The planning and zoning board may authorize the zoning administrator to issue a temporary hardship permit for medical reasons for a manufactured home or travel trailer in a situation where the unit will be used as an accessory dwelling by a member of the property owner's family. The medical disability must be certified by a physician and the member must be an immediate member of the property owner's family. Also, it must be shown by the applicant that the permit is necessary and the dwelling must be located nearby because the family member requires continuous observation. Once the medical hardship has terminated the temporary accessory dwelling shall be removed. (c) An application for a temporary use permit authorizing temporary occupancy for the above-mentioned uses shall be submitted to the zoning administrator for approval. The temporary use permit shall be issued by the county for an appropriate period of time not to exceed 12-month increments. The owner of such temporary nonconforming use must agree to remove the temporary use upon expiration of the permit. The applicant can seek permit renewal in one-year increments if necessity continues beyond the initial year. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XIV, § 14-4) Secs. 20-589—20-609. - Reserved. ARTICLE XIV. - ZONING DISTRICTS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 20-610. - Classes of districts. For the purpose of this chapter, the unincorporated area of the county is divided into the following classes of districts or zones: (1) Residential zoning districts.
(2) Commercial zoning districts.
(3) Industrial zoning districts.
(4) Other zoning districts.
(Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1) Sec. 20-611. - Official zoning map. (a) The boundaries of the various districts shall be shown on the official zoning map of the county. The official zoning map is hereby made a part of this chapter by reference, and all notations, references and other information shown thereon shall be a part of this chapter as if set forth herein. (b) The official zoning map, as adopted by the board of commissioners and subsequently amended from time to time by its action, shall be maintained as so revised by the planning and zoning board. The planning and zoning board shall interpret the official zoning map and answer questions concerning district boundary lines and lot lines. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-2) Secs. 20-612—20-640. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - DISTRICT DESCRIPTIONS
Sec. 20-641. - Residential-Agricultural District (R-A). The R-A district is established to provide for rural farm or non-farm residences in areas where intensive land development is unlikely to occur. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.1) Sec. 20-642. - Low Density Residential District (R-1). The R-1 district is established to provide for low-density, non-farm residential uses of land and structures where intensive land development is unlikely to occur. The R-1 district is designed to serve as a transition between the R-A and R-2 districts. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.2) Sec. 20-643. - General Residential District (R-2). The R-2 district is established to provide for the development of medium density single-family and two-family residential uses. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.3) Sec. 20-644. - High-Density Residential (R-3). The R-3 district is established to provide for medium-density to high-density single-family, two-family and multifamily residential developments. This district includes: multifamily residential dwellings such as townhouse residential units at a density of not greater than eight units per gross acre and apartment residential units at a density of not greater than 14 units per gross acre. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.4) Sec. 20-645. - Neighborhood Commercial District (C-1). The C-1 district is established to provide decentralized areas for the retail sales of goods and for personal services which provide the everyday necessities and conveniences of local residents. This district is intended to permit only those nonresidential commercial uses of land and structures which blend smoothly into the character of adjoining residential areas. It is further intended to exclude all activities which generate perceptible light or noise or attract traffic from outside the immediate neighborhood. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.5) Sec. 20-646. - General Commercial District (C-2). The C-2 district is established to provide for both highway commercial and planned commercial shopping or service centers. This district is intended to be utilized by those commercial uses which cater to community and regional shoppers as well as the traveling public. These commercial uses occupy relatively large sites and require access to major thoroughfares. It is intended that this district be located at major road intersections as provided by the county's development plan. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.6) Sec. 20-647. - Heavy Commercial District (C-3). The C-3 district is established to provide areas for distribution, sales, service or storage activities involving goods or equipment requiring extensive indoor or outdoor spaces, large or specialized handling equipment or significant truck or rail transportation. These uses generate limited emissions and noise which make them incompatible with other commercial or residential uses. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.7) Sec. 20-648. - Light Industrial District (M-1). The M-1 district is established to provide areas for industry in locations which lie near residential areas or which are served by major transportation facilities and adequate utilities, but are not feasible or highly desirable for conventional industrial development because of proximity to residential, recreational, retail or related developments. The regulations of this district are intended to encourage development compatible with uses of residential property adjoining or surrounding the district, with suitable open spaces, landscaping and parking area. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.8) Sec. 20-649. - General Industrial District (M-2). The M-2 district is established to provide areas for manufacturing, assembling, fabricating, warehousing and related activities. These uses generate some emissions and have some adverse effects on surrounding properties and are not compatible with primary commercial, institutional and residential uses. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(02), art. XV, § 15-1.9) Sec. 20-650. - Professional District (P-1). The P-1 district is established to provide for the development of structures for professional services which do not generate large volumes of traffic, noise or other harmful effects on adjoining residential areas.
