(1) The county shall give notice of the meeting published in a newspaper of general circulation at least twice per week for two weeks immediately preceding the date of the meeting. The cost of publication shall be the applicant's responsibility. (2) The notice shall state the time, place, and purpose of the meeting. (3) The purpose of the public meeting shall be to discuss the waste management needs, to describe the siting process to be followed, and to allow for public input. (4) The meeting shall be conducted by the county or municipal governing body or its designee. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XIV(A)) Sec. 32-131. - Submission to board; time limits; fee required. (a) The applicant shall submit to the board of commissioners 12 copies of all information required by federal and state agencies for the facility for which it requests a letter of assurance at the time such information is submitted to the state and federal government. The review procedure shall not begin nor shall the application be designated as complete until such time as all required data are submitted and the appropriate fees are paid, or suitable arrangements for payment have been approved by the board of commissioners. (b) A designee of the board of county commissioners shall compile copies of all reports, applications, minutes of meetings, reports by consultants and similar materials. These materials shall be placed in one location with free access to the public and be made available for copying any portion or all of any document at cost. (c) Within 45 days of the submission of the application, the board of commissioners shall set a time for a public hearing so that the applicant can present his plans and answer questions regarding the same. (d) The applicant shall be required to pay for notice to be published at least twice in the county's legal organ prior to the hearing. Notice shall be published beginning at least seven but not more than 45 days prior to the date of the hearing. The notice shall state the time, place, and purpose of the hearing. Copies of all ads or a certification from the publisher must be submitted to the board prior to each hearing. (e) After the hearing, the board of commissioners shall have 60 days in which to determine if the application is complete and shall mail notice of its determination to the applicant. If the application is not complete, the applicant will have six months to complete the application. However, the applicant may at the end of six months make a showing of cause to the board of commissioners, and, if the board of commissioners finds that the delay is justified and in good faith, they can grant the applicant a maximum three-month extension. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XIV(B)—(F)) Sec. 32-132. - Notification to adjoining property owners. Once a completed application is submitted to the county, the applicant shall be required to send a letter via first class mail to all adjoining property owners, as shown on the tax records of the county on the date of the application, and to all property owners where any portion of their property is within 1,000 feet of the boundary of the facility. This notice shall be required to state that the applicant is seeking a letter of assurance for a solid waste management facility. Certification of this notice must be provided to the board, along with a list of all owners prior to the public meeting for public comment on the completed application. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XIV(G)) Sec. 32-133. - Analysis and reports by county staff, consultants; time limit. (a) Each application shall require an analysis conducted by the county staff and a consultant or consultants selected by the board of commissioners. The analysis shall be completed within 90 days from the day the application is determined to be complete. In certain instances where the complexity of the application requires more than the usual 90 days, the county staff and/or consultant may request an additional 60 days from the board of commissioners, and the proponent has the option of requesting the board of commissioners to extend the analysis period to allow time for responding to staff and/or consultant requests for additional information on a completed application. In the event the integrated long-range solid waste management plan shall not be completed by the end of the analysis period, the consultant or staff may request an additional 90 days to allow for the completion of the plan. (b) The county staff and each consultant shall make reports on the application to the board of commissioners at their meetings. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XIV(H), (I)) Sec. 32-134. - Meeting for public comment; notice given; conduct of meeting. (a) The board of commissioners shall call a public meeting for public comment on the completed application along with the analysis of county staff and consultants. The purpose of this meeting shall be for public review of the application. The staff shall give notice by regular mail of the time and place of the public meeting to the owner and adjacent property owners as specified on the map. Said notice shall be mailed not less than 14 days prior to the date specified thereon. Notice of a public meeting shall be posted by the applicant on the proposed facility property on each and every street of access not less than 14 days prior to the date specified thereon. Said posted notice shall be at intervals of not greater than 1,500 feet. The applicant shall also place notice in the county newspaper not less than 14 days prior to the dates specified thereon. (b) At the public meeting for public comment, the applicant shall again present its application and any supplemental information requested by the board of commissioners. The board members shall have the opportunity to ask questions of the staff, consultants, any experts, the applicant, supporters and opponents. The hearing shall be transcribed or recorded so that it may be transcribed later if necessary. The applicant and supporters shall be granted equal time as opponents. The minimum time allowed per side is 15 minutes. The board may allow more time than the minimum if the application is complex, or the number of witnesses warrants a further extension. If the board determines that there are a great number of opponents with the same interest (for example, members of the same neighborhood), the board may require that a spokesman be designated. The opponents may also be represented by an attorney. The applicant, supporters and opponents shall have the right to provide testimony, including expert testimony, in support of their position. Each party shall have a reasonable opportunity to ask questions of the other side in an orderly manner as controlled by the board. (c) Within 45 days after receipt of the final analysis, complete application and public comment, the county staff and consultants shall make a recommendation to the board of commissioners at a public meeting whether to accept the application, deny it, or accept it with modifications. This recommendation shall be made to the full board of commissioners. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XIV(J)—(L)) Sec. 32-135. - Issuance of letter of assurance; evaluation criteria. (a) The county commission shall issue a letter of assurance for any solid waste management facility in the county, as required by state law and regulations, if such facility complies with the location standards and is consistent with the Jefferson County Solid Waste Management Plan. (b) The board of commissioners, however, before deciding whether to accept the proposal or to accept it with modifications, shall make the following determinations: (1) That there is a bona fide need for the facility and there is no reasonable alternative facility which will pose a lesser threat to the environment. (2) That the construction and operation of the facility will not pose an unreasonable health or environmental risk to the surrounding locality. (3) That the applicant (or facility operator) has the capability and financial resources to construct, operate and maintain the facility. (4) That the applicant or operator has taken or consented in writing to take any and all reasonable measures to comply with the applicable federal, state and local regulations and ordinances. (5) That the applicant's plan represents the best available technology for handling the waste and the applicant has demonstrated that it will employ the best management practices in handling the waste at the proposed facility. (6) Whether the proposed use will have a negative impact to traffic on adjacent streets and in regard to adjacent residential, commercial and industrial uses. (7) Whether the proposed use is compatible with the surrounding properties, uses, and governmentally regulated facilities. (8) Whether the proposed use will have a negative impact on health, safety, aesthetics, property value, or other elements of the community. (9) If there are environmentally sensitive areas on the subject property, whether the proposed plans adequately protect those areas. (10) That the facility is compatible with the county's integrated long-range solid waste management plan, taking into account alternative methods of management such as recycling. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XV(A)) Sec. 32-136. - Rendering of decision at next meeting. (a) At its next scheduled meeting, the board of commissioners shall make its decision to grant the letter of assurance, deny it, or grant it with specified conditions. (b) Each board member shall prepare a written decision or decisions to be voted on by the board at the next scheduled meeting. Board members may individually meet with the county attorney's office to prepare a written decision. (c) Written decisions should be based on the evidence in the record and the criteria in this article. (d) At the next scheduled meeting any board member may put forward a written decision to be voted on. Written decisions may be supplemented with further conditions proposed at the meeting. No vote shall be final until the board of commissioners adopts a written decision. (e) Any proposal shall be specifically conditioned to the site plan, maps, elevation renderings, and other detailed plans to ensure that the development is erected in accordance with the presented materials. The approval may also impose additional conditions, if the conditions are designed to minimize the impact of the use on the neighboring property, streets, and so forth. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XV(B)—(F)) Sec. 32-137. - Appeal process. In the event that an application is denied, the applicant shall have the right to appeal to the Superior Court of Jefferson County within 30 days. The applicant shall file a copy of the appeal with the clerk of the board of commissioners, and the clerk shall forward a copy of the entire record (including evidence submitted by all sides) to the Superior Court as soon as is practicable, along with the minutes of the hearings, copies of the tapes or transcriptions of the hearings, the written decision, a copy of this article, and all other relevant ordinances, maps and documents. (Res. of 6-14-2005, § XVI) Secs. 32-138—32-157. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - COUNTY COLLECTION CONTAINERS
Sec. 32-158. - Purpose. In order to govern and police the unincorporated area of the county for the purpose of protecting and preserving the health, safety, welfare and morals of the citizens thereof, the garbage and solid waste disposal regulations in this article are hereby adopted. (Code 1996, § 54-27) Sec. 32-159. - Administration and enforcement. The sheriff, his designated representative or constable is hereby granted and shall hereafter have the power and authority to administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the collection and disposal of garbage and solid waste in the county. (Code 1996, § 54-28) Sec. 32-160. - Acceptable waste. The county has placed garbage and solid waste collection containers in several locations or collection areas and the county may from time to time hereafter provide other such collection containers and collection areas in the unincorporated areas of the county, and only household garbage or solid waste, domestic kitchen refuse and discarded food, beverages and beverage containers, newspapers, publications, clothing, wearing apparel and discarded wrappings or containers, and such other household and nonhousehold items sufficiently small in size as to not impair the intended use and maintenance of the collection containers, may be dumped or placed in such garbage and solid waste containers as provided by the county. (Code 1996, § 54-29) Sec. 32-161. - Placement of items within container. It shall be unlawful and in violation of this article to dump or place any items outside collection containers or to leave any items at collection areas unless the items have been dumped or placed inside one or more of the collection containers located at the collection area. (Code 1996, § 54-30) Sec. 32-162. - Dumping unacceptable items. (a) It shall be unlawful and in violation of this article to dump, place or leave any other items, property or matter at any garbage and solid waste collection area or in any collection container at any collection area except as provided in section 32-160. (b) It shall be unlawful and in violation of this article to dump, place or leave bricks, blocks, rocks, lumber, asphalt, cement, concrete, concrete products or waste, roofing, sheetrock, leaves, limbs, bushes, trees, roots, dead animals, appliances, equipment, bedsprings, mattresses, furniture, fixtures, motors, engines, chemical wastes, industrial or commercial waste or rubbish, scrap metal, fence wire, vehicles or parts thereof, building materials or supplies, and inorganic solid material of any type or kind, except as authorized in section 32-160, at any garbage or solid waste collection area or in any collection container. (Code 1996, § 54-31) Sec. 32-163. - Scavenging. Scavenging from any collection container is prohibited, and it shall be unlawful and in violation of this article for any person except as fully authorized by the board of commissioners to enter, examine, and sift through the contents of or remove any matter from any collection container. (Code 1996, § 54-32) Sec. 32-164. - Burning, otherwise damaging containers. It shall be unlawful and in violation of this article to set any fire, to allow a fire to continue to burn, or in any other way attempt to damage or destroy the garbage and solid waste collection containers provided by the county. (Code 1996, § 54-33) Sec. 32-165. - Use by nonresidents. The placement of garbage and solid waste collection containers in several locations or collection areas is for the convenience and use in accordance with the provisions of this article of county residents only. It shall be unlawful and in violation of this article for any person to dump, place or leave any item at such garbage and solid waste collection area or in any collection container unless such person is a resident of the county. (Code 1996, § 54-34) Sec. 32-166. - Dumping by commercial collectors. It shall be unlawful and in violation of this article for any person engaged in the business of any type of garbage and solid waste collection to dump, place or leave garbage and solid waste collected in the conduct of business at any garbage and solid waste collection area or in any collection container. (Code 1996, § 54-35) Secs. 32-167—32-185. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - WASTE COLLECTION AND CONTROL DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 32-186. - Prohibited waste deposits. (a) It shall be unlawful to dump, deposit, throw or leave, or to cause or permit, the dumping, depositing, placing, throwing or leaving of litter, waste or scrap tires at any place in the county, including, without limitation, any public or private property in this county or any waters in this county, unless such litter or waste originates in this county; and: (1) The property is designated and permitted by the state or by the board of commissioners, or its duly designated agent, for disposal of litter and waste, and the person is authorized to use such property; and (2) The litter or waste is placed into a receptacle or a container installed on such property. However, any litter or waste placed into such a receptacle or container installed on such property must not be allowed to accumulate for an unreasonable period of time, and in no event shall it be allowed to accumulate to the point of overflowing the container or receptacle or to a point where the container or receptacle may not be closed. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or place waste unless authorized to do so by law or by a duly issued permit: (1) In or on any public highway, road, street, alley, or thoroughfare, including any portion of the right-of-way thereof, or on any other public lands, except in containers of areas lawfully provided for such dumping; (2) In or on any freshwater lake, river, canal or stream or creek; or (3) In or on any public or private property, unless such dumping will not adversely affect the public health and is not in violation of any other local, state or federal law, rule or regulation. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 2(b), (c)) Sec. 32-187. - Transportation of waste. (a) It shall be unlawful to drive or operate a vehicle in the county hauling wet or moist litter or waste which leaks, flows freely or spills from such vehicle. (b) Any litter or waste hauled on a moving vehicle in the county shall be covered or secured in such a manner that the litter or waste will not blow or escape from said vehicle while moving or parked on public streets or roadways in the county. (c) It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to transport litter or waste on any public streets or roadways in the county without suitable coverings or other restraint devices securely fastening such litter or waste to the vehicle so as to prevent any materials from being deposited on the roads or adjoining areas of the county. However, this section shall not prohibit the necessary spreading of any substance in public road maintenance or public road construction operations. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 3) Sec. 32-188. - Waste receptacles. (a) All garbage or litter containers or receptacles shall be maintained in as sanitary a manner as is reasonably possible consistent with its use for garbage and litter disposal. (b) Persons using garbage or litter containers or receptacles shall deposit all authorized garbage and refuse in the container or receptacle. (c) No person shall deposit any burning or smoldering material in any such container and receptacle. (d) No person shall set fire to the contents of any such container or receptacle. (e) No dead animals shall be deposited in any such container or receptacle. (f) No person shall deposit large, non-compactable articles in such containers or receptacles such as stoves, refrigerators, bed springs, mattresses, tires, large tree limbs, air conditioning units, or similar items. (g) No one shall deposit any flammable or explosive materials in any such containers or receptacles. (h) No person shall place or scatter litter or waste in or around such containers or receptacles. (i) No one shall scavenge or collect items from in or around such containers or receptacles. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 4) Sec. 32-189. - Accumulation of waste prohibited. (a) No owner or occupant of any premises in the unincorporated areas of the county shall allow litter or waste to accumulate thereon. (b) No owner or occupant of any such property shall bury or burn litter or waste without prior authorization and permission from the applicable regulatory agency, including, but not limited to, the environmental protection agency, environmental protection division or the state forestry service. Nothing in this provision shall authorize or be construed to permit the burial or burning of any material which is otherwise prohibited by state or federal law. (c) No owner or occupant of any property shall allow the accumulation on his premises, of garbage or waste where such material creates or causes a health hazard to neighbors or other citizens, or which is unsightly or emits foul or obnoxious odors. (d) It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to the contents of, indiscriminately scatter or disperse the contents of, or otherwise vandalize any containers used for the storage or dumping of litter or waste. (e) The conduct described in this section shall constitute a separate violation of this article for each day the garbage or waste material remains on such premises. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 5) Sec. 32-190. - Responsibilities of owner or occupant of premises. The owner or occupant of any premises shall be responsible for the sanitary handling and disposition of garbage, litter, waste, scrap tires and refuse on the premises used or occupied by such person. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 2(a)) Sec. 32-191. - State rules and law applicable to scrap tire generators, carriers and retailers. All persons defined as scrap tire generators, scrap tire carriers, or tire retailers shall be subject to rules as defined in Ga. Admin. Code § 391-3-4.19 and handle scrap tires in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 12-8-20 et seq. and the rules for solid waste management, Ga. Admin. Code ch. 391-3-4 applicable to solid waste. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 2) Sec. 32-192. - Yard trimmings. (a) Yard trimming shall not be placed in, or mixed with, solid waste. Yard trimmings shall not be disposed of at any solid waste disposal facility having liners and leachate collection systems or requiring vertical expansion within the county. (b) Yard trimmings shall be sorted and stockpiled or chipped, composted, used as mulch or otherwise beneficially reused or recycled to the maximum extent feasible. Any yard trimmings to be collected by any entity other than the property owner shall be sorted and stored in such a manner as to facilitate collection, composting or other handling. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 10) Sec. 32-193. - Recycling policy. The board of commissioners hereby finds that it is in the best interest of the citizens of the county, in order to promote the health, safety, welfare and morals of the citizens of the county, to recycle as many waste materials as possible in order to reduce the accumulation of litter and garbage and solid waste material within the county and to reduce the overall solid waste materials which must be properly disposed. Therefore, it is the policy of the board of commissioners to encourage recycling whenever practicable. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 11) Secs. 32-194—32-224. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 32-225. - Enforcement. Enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the county code enforcement officer or his designee or the county sheriff or his designee. Sec. 32-226. - Right of entry for inspection. Any person or persons authorized to enforce this article shall be empowered to enter any property, upon reasonable cause, at reasonable times, in order to inspect the property for violations of this article, subject to the condition that to allow entry on private property for inspection, the alleged violation of this article must be visible from a public road or right-of-way, or upon such officer having received a complaint by a resident of the county alleging a violation of this article. Sec. 32-227. - Authority of magistrate court to act on complaints. The magistrate court of the county shall be authorized to issue summonses for hearing on alleged violations of this article upon written accusation of any person sui juris alleging such violation. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 7) Sec. 32-228. - Evidentiary presumptions. (a) Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle, boat, airplane or other conveyance in violation of this article, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of the conveyance has violated this article. (b) Whenever any litter which is dumped, deposited, thrown or left on public or private property in violation of this article is discovered to contain any article or articles, including, but not limited to, letters, bills, publications or other writings which display the name of a person thereon in such a manner as to indicate that the article belongs or belonged to such person, it shall be a rebuttable presumption that such person has violated this article. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 9) Sec. 32-229. - Civil remedies and nuisance abatement. In the event that any person, firm or corporation violates any provision of this article, the county attorney or other appropriate authority of the county may, in addition to other remedies, institute an action for injunction, mandamus, or other appropriate action or proceeding to prevent such unlawful act or to correct or abate such violation. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 8) Sec. 32-230. - Penalties. (a) Any person, firm or corporation violating any portion of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, in the magistrate court of the county, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $1,000.00, or up to 60 days imprisonment, or both. Each day the violation continues shall be a separate offense. However, this section shall not preclude the county from choosing to seek a civil redress in a court of competent jurisdiction in addition to the criminal prosecution, it being the intent of the county to have both the civil and criminal rights of prosecution in this area. (b) In addition, in the sound discretion of the magistrate court, the court may impose any or all of the following additional penalties: (1) The violator may be directed to pick up and remove from any public street or highway or public right-of-way for a distance not to exceed one mile, any litter the person has deposited and any and all litter deposited thereon by anyone else prior to the date of execution or sentence; (2) The person may be directed to pick up and remove litter from any public park, private right-of-way, or, with the prior permission of the legal owner or tenant in lawful possession of such property, any private property upon which it can be established by competent evidence that the person has deposited litter thereon, and all litter deposited thereon by anyone prior to the date of execution of sentence; or (3) The court may order the publication of the names of persons convicted of violating this article. (c) In the case of an improper garbage or waste disposal site, the property owner, contractor, developer, builder or other person responsible for the property shall cause the property to be cleaned and to come into full compliance with this article. The county shall not be responsible for any costs of cleanup or remediation. (Ord. of 7-13-1999(01), § 6) Secs. 32-231—32-253. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - FEES
Sec. 32-254. - Waste collection and management fees. All solid waste collection and management fees shall be in the amount provided in the county fee schedule. Sec. 32-255. - Exemptions; request procedure. (a) Business with own dumpster. The owner of a commercial business which has its own dumpster will be exempt from paying the solid waste maintenance fee if the owner has completed a request for solid waste maintenance fee exemption form. If the commercial business has more than one owner, the owners may decide which owner gets the exemption. In any case only one exemption from payment will be granted. This exemption is not good for other family members, employees or neighbors or club members. (b) Manufactured home park with leased dumpster. A manufactured home park that has a dumpster leased from the county or a commercial carrier will be exempt from paying the solid waste maintenance fee. The park must have at least one dumpster for every ten connections. One dumpster will be required for each ten units or part thereof. If it is subsequently found that the dumpster or dumpsters have been removed after the request for exemption has been granted, the manufactured home park owner will be assessed the solid waste maintenance fee for an entire year as if it had just opened. (c) Uninhabited manufactured home. (1) If a manufactured home owner files a request for solid waste maintenance fee exemption because the manufactured home is uninhabitable, a member of the tax assessor's office or other appointed individual will inspect the unit. If the unit is deemed to be uninhabitable by the county, the unit will be exempted from the solid waste maintenance fee. (2) If such manufactured home is to be utilized as a storage building, it will be transferred from personal property to real property on the tax digest. The owner of the manufactured home is to be immediately notified of this change. The owner will be required to affix a county-provided decal on the storage building (manufactured home), on the right side of the front door, indicating that the building is no longer designated a manufactured home but is a storage building. (d) Hunting clubs. (1) The land owner where a hunting club is located will be assessed the solid waste maintenance fee for each service connection. The hunting club that leases a dumpster from the county or from a commercial carrier will be exempt from paying the solid waste maintenance fee if the owner has completed a request for solid waste maintenance fee exemption form. (2) The club must have at least one dumpster for every ten service connections. A dumpster will be required for each subsequent part of ten units. If it is subsequently found that the dumpster or dumpsters have been removed after the request for exemption has been granted, the hunt club owner will be assessed the solid waste maintenance fee for an entire year as if it had just opened. (3) If an individual pays the solid waste maintenance fee at their primary residence in the unincorporated portion of the county or in the City of Avera, his service connection in a hunting club will be exempt from the fee requirement after submittal of the request for solid waste maintenance fee exemption form. Their exemption within the park will affect the number of units within a park requirements, (the exempted connection will not count against the ten-unit limitation for one dumpster requirement). (e) Residents of Avera or unincorporated areas of the county. Those citizens whose residence is in the unincorporated portions of the county or in the City of Avera who have their solid waste collected by a city within their service area or collected by a commercial solid waste hauler will be exempted by completing the request for solid waste maintenance fee exemption form. (f) Churches. All buildings owned by a recognized church will be automatically exempt from paying the solid waste maintenance fee.

div.head: Chapter 34 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Revenue and taxation generally, O.C.G.A. § 48-1-1 et seq.; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; county tax officials and administration, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-100 et seq.; county taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-220 et seq.; miscellaneous local administration provisions, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-380; county sales and use taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-8-110 et seq.; taxes on tobacco products, O.C.G.A. § 48-11-1 et seq.; levy of occupation taxes by counties and municipalities on certain businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.; imposition of regulatory fees by local governments on certain businesses, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-8 et seq.
Sec. 34-1. - Joint county and municipal sales and use tax. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-8-80 et seq., a combination city-county local sales and use tax is hereby levied by the board of commissioners of the county. (Code 1996, § 58-1; Ord. of 3-28-1979) Sec. 34-2. - Foreclosure of ad valorem tax liens. (a) The county has elected to follow the requirements of O.C.G.A. title 48, ch. 4, art. 5 (O.C.G.A. § 48-4-75 et seq.) relating to tax sales, regarding judicial in rem foreclosures of tax executions. (b) The county tax commissioner shall have the authority to commence tax foreclosure and to file petitions with the county superior court in accordance with said statutes. (Ord. No. 007-95, 10-17-1995)

div.head: Chapter 36 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Motor vehicles and traffic, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 et seq.; uniform rules of the road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; off-road vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-7-1 et seq.; equipment and inspection of motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-1 et seq.; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; use of speed detection devices, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 36-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-1 through 40-6-395 of that chapter, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1 are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of this county with like effect as if recited in this chapter. (b) Unless another penalty is expressly provided by law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished in accordance with section 1-15. (Code 1996, § 62-1) Sec. 36-2. - County transit system vans. The county's rules and regulations adopted by resolution of April 9, 1991, for department of transportation section 18 vans operated by the county transit system are on file in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. Sec. 36-3. - Speed detection device authorized. The county sheriff's department is approved and authorized to use speed detection devices in the process of its law enforcement activities as permitted by O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. (Res. of 2-10-2004) State Law reference— Georgia Peace Officer Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; authority for use or speed detection devices by county law enforcement officer, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2; requirements that county obtain state permit, O.C.G.A. § 40-14-2. Sec. 36-4. - Transit customer complaint policy. (a) Issues. Complaints can include late pickup, rude driver, or discrimination. There may be other situations for complaint as well. (b) Filing. Riders can file their complaints, comments, suggestions, and concerns in the following way: U.S. mail: Mail to Mr. Paul Bryan, Jefferson County Administrator, P.O. Box 658, Louisville, Georgia 30434. (c) Feedback review process. All feedback from customers is valued and will be reviewed by the county administrator. After review, the administrator will distribute the customer communication to the transit supervisor. Questions regarding discrimination or bias will be sent to the agency equal opportunity officer. (d) Feedback acknowledgement. Anyone who submits a comment, complaint, or service suggestion concerning Jefferson Transit shall receive a response, provided they give legible contact information, within seven business days. (e) Customer appeals process. Any person who is dissatisfied with the response they receive from the county administrator is welcome to appeal the decision. A review team consisting of the county administrator, a customer relations officer, the Jefferson Transit Supervisor, and one other staff member will review customer appeals. (f) Information about policy. Information about the customer complaint policy, including how to submit a complaint, will be made available to the riders. (g) Reporting. The county administrator shall compile a summary of rider responses for the board, staff, and employees for use in reviewing and evaluating service. (h) Protection from retribution. Customers of Jefferson Transit will be able to submit feedback without fear of retribution from the agency. Jefferson Transit will appropriately discipline any employee that retaliates against a customer. Secs. 36-5—36-26. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - JUNKED AND ABANDONED VEHICLES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; jurisdiction of magistrate court to abate nuisance, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-5; authority to provide by ordinance for removal and disposal of junked vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-4; abandoned motor vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq.; when police officers may remove vehicles, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-206; removal of improperly parked cars, O.C.G.A. § 44-1-13.
Sec. 36-27. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Inoperative or junk condition includes, but shall not be limited to, any automobile, vehicle, trailer of any kind or type, or contrivance, or a part thereof, the condition of which is one or more of the following: (1) Wrecked. (2) Dismantled. (3) Partially dismantled. (4) Inoperative. (5) Abandoned. (6) Discarded. (7) Scrapped. (8) Does not have a valid license plate attached thereto. (Code 1996, § 38-41; Ord. No. 004-95, § 400, 3-14-1995) Sec. 36-28. - Parking vehicles with invalid license plates. Any automobile, vehicle or trailer of any kind or type, without a valid license plate attached thereto, shall not be parked or stand on any property unless it shall be in a completely enclosed building, unless the property is premises of a legally operated business enterprise in which the presence of such vehicles is necessary. (Code 1996, § 38-42; Ord. No. 004-95, § 200, 3-14-1995) Sec. 36-29. - Parking prohibition; exceptions. No automobile, vehicle or trailer of any kind or type, which shall be inoperative or in a junk condition, shall be parked or stand on any property unless it shall be: (1) In an enclosed building; or (2) On the premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful manner, when necessary to the operation of such business enterprise. (Code 1996, § 38-43; Ord. No. 004-95, § 300, 3-14-1995) Sec. 36-30. - Nuisances not authorized. Nothing in this division shall authorize the maintenance of a public or private nuisance as defined under the provisions of law. (Code 1996, § 38-44; Ord. No. 004-95, § 500, 3-14-1995) Sec. 36-31. - Supplemental nature of division. This article shall not be the exclusive regulation of discarded, dismantled, wrecked, scrapped, ruined or junk motor vehicles, or contrivances within the unincorporated limits of the county, but shall be supplemental in addition to other regulations and ordinances of the county and statutes or provisions of law heretofore and hereafter enacted by the county, state or other legal entity or agency have jurisdiction. (Code 1996, § 38-45; Ord. No. 004-95, § 600, 3-14-1995) Sec. 36-32. - Removal. In all instances where the owner of any abandoned or junk motor vehicle or trailer cannot be determined, or the owner of any junk or abandoned motor vehicle or trailer refuses to give consent for the county to remove any junk or abandoned motor vehicle or trailer which has been determined to constitute a health hazard or unsightly nuisance, such junk or abandoned motor vehicle or trailer shall be removed under the authority and provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-11-1 et seq. (Code 1996, § 38-46; Ord. No. 004-95, § 700, 3-14-1995)

div.head: Chapter 38 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- State Law reference— Public utilities generally, O.C.G.A. § 46-1-1 et seq.; water resources, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-1 et seq.; public water systems, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-170 et seq.; water supply, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-470; sewage and waste disposal, O.C.G.A. § 12-5-29 et seq.; dumping certain wastes in storm or sanitary sewers prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 12-8-2; adoption of ordinances, rules and regulations relating to payment for street improvements and construction of water, gas and sewer connections, payment of costs of connections, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-7.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 38-1. - Fees and other charges. Security deposit fees, connection fees, water and sewer rate schedules, and related charges, fees and deposits are listed in a schedule of fees and charges on file in the office of the clerk of the board of commissioners. Secs. 38-2—38-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - WATER SERVICE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 38-21. - Application; deposit. To obtain water, a customer must make application for water service at the county water department. A cash security deposit in an amount determined by the board of commissioners from time to time must be paid. (Code 1996, § 66-26(a); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-22. - Connection fee. There will be a connection fee per connection in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. Larger commercial operations, multiple dwelling units, industrial users and fire protection shall be governed by special agreements to be negotiated between the county and the consumer. (Code 1996, § 66-26(b); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-23. - Minimum monthly charge. There shall be a minimum monthly charge in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. Larger commercial operations, multiple dwelling units, industrial users and fire protection shall be governed by special agreements to be negotiated between the county and the consumer. (Code 1996, § 66-26(c); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-24. - Rate schedule. The water rate schedule shall be in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. Larger commercial operations, multiple-dwelling units, industrial users and fire protection organizations shall be governed by special agreements to be negotiated between the county and the consumer. (Code 1996, § 66-26(d); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-25. - Violations causing discontinuance of service. A consumer's service will be discontinued if he sells water to another person or permits any other person to tie into his service. (Code 1996, § 66-26(e); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-26. - Penalty for unlawful connection. Any person who unlawfully connects to a consumer water line shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15. (Code 1996, § 66-26(f); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-27. - Due date; penalties for late payment. (a) Bills are due within 20 days from due date. For bills past due 20 days from due date, there will be a ten percent delinquent penalty. For bills past due 40 days, the water will be shut off. (b) For bills past due over 60 days, water service is discontinued, and the security deposit will be applied to the account. Any balance will be collected in the usual manner provided by law for collections of debts. Any credit balance will be refunded to the customer. (c) Service disconnected for nonpayment of a bill will be restored only after payment of the bill plus a ten percent penalty charge plus a service charge for each meter reconnected in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. (d) Any consumer whose service has been disconnected for nonpayment of services and who reconnects service without proper authority will be subject to a penalty of $50.00 plus other penalty charges. (Code 1996, § 66-26(g); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-28. - Change of occupancy. A customer must give the water department a three-day notice in person or in writing if water service is to be disconnected or to change occupancies. Unless due notice is given, the customer will be responsible for service until due notice is given to the water department. (Code 1996, § 66-26(h); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-29. - Application for new premises. New customers must apply at the county water department with appropriate identification for services within 48 hours after occupying a premises and failure to do so will make him liable for payment of water consumed from the previous meter reading. (Code 1996, § 66-26(i); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-30. - Amendments and exceptions. No part of this policy shall be altered, and no exception to rules and procedures shall be allowed for any customer without approval of the board of commissioners. (Code 1996, § 66-26(j); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Secs. 38-31—38-48. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - OUTDOOR LANDSCAPE WATERING
Sec. 38-49. - Compliance required. No person shall use or allow the use of water in violation of the restrictions on outdoor water use contained in this division. (Ord. No. 001-11, art. II(I), 1-13-2011) Sec. 38-50. - Enforcement authority. The county code enforcement officer shall be the enforcement authority for this division. The county administrator may also authorize other departments as may be deemed necessary to support enforcement. (Ord. No. 001-11, art. II(II), 1-13-2011) Sec. 38-51. - Outdoor watering hours restricted; exceptions. Outdoor watering for purposes of planting, growing, managing, or maintaining ground cover, trees, shrubs, or other plants in the unincorporated areas of the county may occur only between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m.; provided, however, that this limitation shall not place any limitation upon the following outdoor water uses: (1) Commercial raising, harvesting, or storing of crops, feeding, breeding, or managing livestock or poultry; the commercial productions or storing of feed for use in the production of livestock, including but not limited to, cattle, calves, swine, hogs, goats, sheep, and rabbits, or for use in the production of poultry, including, but not limited to chickens, hens, ratites, and turkey; producing plants, trees, or animals, or the commercial production of aquaculture, horticultural, dairy, livestock, eggs, and apiarian products or as otherwise defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3; (2) Capture and reuse of cooling system condensate or stormwater in compliance with applicable county ordinances and state guidelines; (3) Reuse of gray water in compliance with O.C.G.A. § 31-4-5.2 and applicable local board of health regulations; (4) Use of reclaimed wastewater by a designated user from a system permitted by the environmental protection division of the state department of natural resources to provide reclaimed wastewater; (5) Watering personal food gardens; (6) Watering new and replanted plant, seed, or turf in landscapes, golf courses, or sports turf fields during installation and for a period of 30 days immediately following the date of installation; (7) Drip irrigation or irrigation using soaker hoses; (8) Hand watering with a hose with automatic cutoff or handheld container; (9) Use of water withdrawn from private water wells or surface water by an owner or operator of property if such well or surface water is on said property; (10) Watering horticultural crops held for sale, resale, or installation; (11) Watering athletic fields; golf courses or public turf grass recreational areas; (12) Installation, maintenance, or calibration of irrigation systems; or (13) Hydro-seeding. (Ord. No. 001-11, art. I, 1-13-2011) Sec. 38-52. - Criminal and alternative penalties. Any violations of this division may also be enforced by a citation or accusation returnable to the magistrate court or by any other legal means as set forth in this Code. (Ord. No. 001-11, art. II(III), 1-13-2011) Secs. 38-53—38-77. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - SEWER SERVICE
Sec. 38-78. - Application and deposit. To obtain sewer service a customer must make application for sewer service at the county water department. A cash security deposit in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners must be paid. (Code 1996, § 66-27(b); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-79. - Connection fee. There will be a per-customer connection fee in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. (Code 1996, § 66-27(c); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-80. - Minimum monthly charge. There shall be a minimum monthly charge in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. (Code 1996, § 66-27(d); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-81. - Rate schedule. The sewer rate schedule shall be in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. (1) This rate schedule contemplates a single consumer, such as a one-family dwelling, a farm dwelling with appurtenances, or a small commercial operation. (2) Larger commercial operations, multiple-dwelling units and industrial users shall be governed by special agreements to be negotiated between the county and the consumer. (Code 1996, § 66-27(e); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-82. - Bill paid with water bill. The bill for sewer service is paid with the water bill and cannot be separated from the water bill. (Code 1996, § 66-27(a); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-83. - Due date; penalties for late payment. (a) Bills are due within 20 days from due date. For bills past due 20 days from due date, there will be a ten percent delinquent penalty. For bills past due 40 days, the water will be shut off. (b) For bills past due over 60 days, water service is discontinued, and the security deposit will be applied to the account. Any balance will be collected in the usual manner provided by law for collections of debts. Any credit balance will be refunded to the customer. (c) Service disconnected for nonpayment of a bill will be restored only after payment of the bill plus a ten percent penalty charge plus a service charge for each meter reconnected in an amount determined from time to time by the board of commissioners. (d) Any consumer whose water service has been disconnected for nonpayment of sewer service charges and who reconnects water service without proper authority will be subject to a penalty of $50.00 plus other penalty charges. (Code 1996, § 66-27(f); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Sec. 38-84. - Amendments; exceptions. No part of this policy shall be altered, and no exception to rules and procedures shall be allowed for any customer without approval of the board of commissioners. (Code 1996, § 66-27(g); Ord. of 4-5-1988) Secs. 38-85—38-111. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SEPTIC TANKS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Regulations for septic tanks or individual sewage management systems in unincorporated areas, conformity prerequisite to building permit, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-5.1.
Sec. 38-112. - Defective septic tanks; repair or connection to county sewer line required. Within 30 days after a septic tank has been found by the county health department to be so defective as to constitute a health hazard and a declaration thereof has been made by the health department to the owner of the tank, the owner shall either repair the septic tank so as to correct the defective condition or shall, if the county's sewer line is available to the owner's property, connect the premises which had been so served by the septic tank to the county's system. (Code 1996, § 42-27; Ord. of 5-10-1983, § 1) Sec. 38-113. - Penalty. Violations of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-15. (Code 1996, § 42-26; Ord. of 5-10-1983, § 2) CODE COMPARATIVE TABLE 1996 CODE This table gives the location within this Code of those sections of the 1996 Code, as supplemented or updated through July 13, 1998, that are included herein.
